headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Unum Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I'd like to turn the conference over to the Senior Vice President of Investo
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Unum Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I'd like to turn the conference over to the Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tom White. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Cynthia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the fourth quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call for Unum. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact. As a r
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Cynthia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the fourth quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call for Unum. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact. As a result, actual results might differ materially from these results suggested by these forward-looking statements. Information concerning factors that could cause results to differ appears in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and are also located in the section titled Cautionary Statement regarding forward-looking statements and risk factors in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2014, and our subsequently filed quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. Our SEC filings can be found in the Investor section of our website at
I'd remind you that these statements in today's call speak only of the date they are made, and we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements.
As we discussed, our financial results this quarter, I'll remind you that our product period results have been adjusted for our retrospective adoption of the accounting standards update for tax credit partnership investments and qualified housing projects. Adjusted prior period results are available on our website in a supplemental exhibit.
A presentation of the most directly comparable GAAP measures and reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures included in today's presentation can be found in our statistical supplement on our website also in the Investor section.
Participating in morning's conference call are Unum's President and CEO, Rick McKenney; CFO, Jack McGarry; as well as the CEOs of our core business segments: Mike Simonds for Unum US; Peter O'Donnell for Unum UK; and Tim Arnold for Colonial Life. With that, I'll turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. We finished 2015 on a strong note with fourth quarter operating income at $0.95 per share. That's an increase of 6.7% over last year, bringing the full year EPS to $3.64.  Whi
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. We finished 2015 on a strong note with fourth quarter operating income at $0.95 per share. That's an increase of 6.7% over last year, bringing the full year EPS to $3.64.  Which is an increase of 3.7%. We ended the year in the middle of outlook range of 2% to 5%, which we're tracking to all year. I'm specially pleased with the balance performance we continue to show on our core business segments. With good levels of premium growth, complimented by stable benefits expense across all lines. This combination helps to drive a strong profit margin and excellent capital generation for the company.
Our financial flexibility continues to be an important asset to us as we move into 2016, as we look to take advantage of the opportunities for profitable growth and to expand our leadership positions in the employee and voluntary benefits market.
I will cover a few highlights for the fourth quarter and then Jack will provide analysis of our results in greater detail. I will start with premium growth in our core business segments, which continue at a healthy and well-balanced pace. For the fourth quarter, premiums in each of our 3 core segments, Unum US., Unum UK and Colonial Life all increased by more than 5%. For Unum US, fourth quarter sales had a difficult conversion given the 25% in the year ago fourth quarter, but for the full year, 2015, we generated, an increase of just over 4%, at the top end of coming in 2015.
In addition, Unum US persistency trends remain favorable and our ongoing focus on renewals helped drive the 5.5% increase in premium income. Unum UK sales in local currency improved in the fourth quarter with growth of 11%, driven largely by strong results in the core market long-term disability sales and large case Group Life sales. Combined with improving persistency and the benefit of a recently acquired a dental business, Unum UK generated 5% growth in premiums in the fourth quarter as well. 
Finally, at Colonial Life, sales growth continues to be quite encouraging. Increasing 5% for the fourth quarter and almost 7% for the full year, helping to generate premium growth of just over 5% for the quarter.
Next, it's important that we've not sacrifice the profitable the of our core businesses to generate this premier growth as our benefits expense to remain stable and was all 3 business segments. In fact, the benefit ratios for the 3 core business segments improved for the full year, 2015, relative to 2014.
Jack will provide additional detail on these trends in his commentary. Given these operating results, we continue to produce a very strong level of capital, which provides us substantial financial flexibility. This flexibility allows us to fund the capital required to grow our business, but also returning capital to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends as we brought back for $27 million of stock in 2015. In addition, we've continue to grow our book value per share with book value now at $35.90, an increase of 8.4% for the year, consistent with the growth we've generated since 2008. 
And finally, the macro environment, including the ongoing low interest rate environment continues to present challenges. Interest rates and investments spreads remain below historical levels and below our portfolio yields. Our focus remains on actively managing through this environment by steadily taking pricing actions, near-term it does continue to dampen our profit growth.
So with these highlights on our fourth quarter performance, I'll have Jack cover our results in greater detail. Jack?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Rick provided a high-level view of our fourth quarter results, and now I want provide a more in-depth review of the operating and business trends we saw in the quarter. I will begin with Unum US, where fourth q
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Rick provided a high-level view of our fourth quarter results, and now I want provide a more in-depth review of the operating and business trends we saw in the quarter. I will begin with Unum US, where fourth quarter operating income was $214.2 million, an increase of 2.2% on the year-ago quarter of $209.5 million. Premium income growth remains very healthy increasing 5.5% over the year-ago quarter, while the benefit ratio for Unum US segment improves slightly to 71.1% in the quarter compared to 71.3% in the year-ago quarter.
The profitability of Unum US remained strong with an operating ROE of 13.1% for the fourth quarter, and 13.3% for the full year. Within the Unum US segment operating income in our core -- in our group disability business was $66.1 million, an increase of 0.3% from the year-ago quarter of $65.9 million. Premium income increased 5.5% over the year-ago quarter, while we continue to see pressure on net investment income, which declined by 5.7% compared to the year-ago quarter, driven by lower asset levels, lower portfolio yield and lower miscellaneous investment income.
Benefits experienced improved in the fourth quarter relative to the year-ago quarter. The benefit ratio was 81.7% for the fourth quarter compared to 83.7% a year ago, driven primarily by lower claims incidence rates and favorable claim recovery experience in our group long-term disability product line as well as favorable benefits experienced in our group short-term disability line.
Group Life and AD&D operating income was $54.3 million for the fourth quarter, a decline of 8.4% from the year-ago quarter. Premium income continues to grow at a favorable levels, increasing 5.2% over the year-ago quarter. The benefit ratio was 72% for the fourth quarter compared to 70.8% in the year-ago quarter due to a higher average paid claim size, for both the Group Life line and the AD&D line of business. While the benefit ratio was higher on a year-over-year basis, the fourth quarter experience was generally consistent with the 71.8% benefit ratio for the full year, 2015.
Operating income and supplemental and voluntary lines was very strong at $93.8 million in the fourth quarter, an increase of 11.3% compared to $84.3 million in the year-ago quarter. Premium income growth trends were also strong for this line of business, increasing 5.7% in the quarter compared to last year.
From the benefits perspective, results were a line with our expectation. The fourth quarter benefit ratio for the individual disability line was 33.8% on an interest adjusted basis and 48% for the voluntary benefits line.
With Unum UK, operating income was a GBP 24.4 million for the fourth quarter, an increase of 1.2% over the year-ago quarter of GBP 24.1 million. The benefit ratio was 69.9% for the fourth quarter, compared to 68.8% in the year-ago quarter, driven primarily by higher claims incidence trends in the group long-term disability including Group Life business, which are partially offset by group claim recoveries. Overall, profitability of the U.K. segment remains quite favorable, with an operating ROE of 20.6% for the fourth quarter and 18% for the full year.
Colonial Life continues to generate strong consistent result with operating income of $77.6 million, up 4.9% increase over the year-ago quarter of $74 million. The benefit ratio improved to 51.2% for the fourth quarter compared to 52.3% for the year-ago quarter, driven by favorable benefits experienced in the sickness and disability product line. Margin remain strong for Colonial Life with operating ROE of 16.4% this quarter and 16.6% for the full year.
Finally, for the Closed Block, operating income was $28.1 million in the fourth quarter compared to $29.4 million in the year-ago quarter, excluding the 2014 long-term care reserve charge. The benefits experienced by the individual disability line was in line with our expectation. The increase in the interest adjusted loss ratio to 87.2% in the fourth quarter compared to 81% in the year-ago quarter, was largely driven by a reduction in the reserve discount rate to recognize the impact on the future portfolio yields from the higher than normal level of miscellaneous net investment income. 
For the long-term line, the interest-adjusted the loss ratio was 89.7% for the fourth quarter compared to 89.6% for the year-ago quarter excluding the reserve charge.
The underlying risk experienced for long-term care was consistent with our long-term expectation for the full year, 2015, interest-adjusted loss ratio of 87.6% within our expected range of 85% to 90%. 
Regarding the reserve position for long-term care, we feel good about where we finished 2015 in terms of reserve adequacy. For the year, our new money yield exceeded our interest rate assumptions and risk reserves remained within our long-term expectations. In addition, rate increase approvals and implementation are tracking in line with our reserve assumptions. One additional comment on long-term care, the cash flow testing reserve addition were recorded for our new subsidiary First Unum was $68 million at year-end 2015. I will now move to the growth trends we experienced across the company in the quarter.
Again, starting with Unum US, total sales declined by 3.7% for the fourth quarter compared to a year ago. This was not unexpected as we had very strong sales results from the year-ago fourth quarter, and we continue to increase rates during the year. For the full year, Unum US sales increased by 4.2%, which was slightly above the top end of our expectation of 2% to 4% growth. 
Looking at the sales results by product line, LTD sales were flat in the fourth quarter, but increased 7.2% for the full year. STD sales declined by 20% for the fourth quarter, but grew slightly for the full year, increasing by 0.8%. At Group Life and AD&D, sales declined 2.5% for the quarter and 5.6% for the full year, also within Unum US, we had strong sales results in individual disability for the fourth quarter, increasing 30.4% to $21 million, driven by success with large case enrollments. 
Full year sales growth for the individual disability line was 18.8%. Finally, in the voluntary benefits, total sales declined 7.4% for the fourth quarter. Core market voluntary benefits sales showed very good growth while sales were lower against a very strong quarter last year.
Full year 2015 sales and voluntary benefits increased 10.3% with good balance between the core market and large case sales. Our sales outlook for 2016 for Unum US calls for growth rate in the 2% to 4% again. It's slightly that we will quarterly volatility as we did in 2015, particularly given the volatility of timing of large case sales.
Persistency for Unum US continues at healthy levels. For the group lines combined, persistency was 90.3% for the full year, 2015, which was stable with the 90.5% for 2014. Given these sales trends and persistency levels, along with the underlying management of enforcement we generated premium income growth for Unum US this quarter of 5.5%. Full year premium growth was 6.4%, consistent with our long-term outlook for this segment and our strongest rate of growth in many years.
Sales in Unum UK rebounded nicely in the fourth quarter, increasing 11.2% in local currency with the favorable trends in the core market group long-term group disability market line and Group Life. For the full year, sales grew by 6.2%. Persistency in the group disability line was 89.2% for the full year of 2015, off slightly from 2014 levels, but in line with our expectations.
Persistency for the Group Life line continue to recover at 80% for full year 2015, up from 76% in 2014. Premium income growth for the U.K. of this quarter was 5.4% in local currency, including the impact of the acquisition of the dental business in the third quarter, and 2.3% for full year above our expectations of 0% to 2% growth.
Finally, Colonial Life lives elsewhere remain on a positive trend, increasing 5.1% for the fourth quarter and 6.9% for the full year. Growth this quarter was again well-balanced between the commercial market sector, both core markets sales and large case sales in the public sector. In addition, each product lines showed positive year-over-year growth. Persistency for Colonial Life was slightly lower for the year at 78.5% compared to 79.4% for 2014, but premium growth continues to show good momentum, increasing 5.1% in the fourth quarter compared to the year-ago quarter. Full year premium growth was also 5.1% well above the top end of our expectation of 2% to 4% growth.
Overall, we remain very pleased with the growth trends we see in our core business segments as well as the profit margins we're maintaining.
Looking our investment results. New money yields were slightly better in the fourth quarter compared to the first 9 months of 2015. However, today's new money yields remain below our current portfolio yield, so the downward pressure on our portfolio yields and net investment income continues to impact our profitability. We are actively raising prices in our markets to help manage this impact. The credit quality of our investment portfolio remains in very good shape. Our overall default experience relative to the index was again very favorable at 15 basis points for full year 2015, compared to 80 basis points for the index. 
I'd like to give you an update on our energy-related holdings, which totaled $5 billion for 11.6% of our total fixed maturity securities at year-end 2015.
The severe widening of credit spreads in the energy segment's sector during the fourth quarter, reduced the net unrealized gain from $302.8 million as of September 30, 2015, to a net unrealized loss of $51.4 million at December 31, 2015.
We saw relatively more spread widening in the oilfield services and independent oil and gas sectors of our portfolio, as we discussed at our outlook in December, these sectors tend to be the most sensitive companies to oil prices. The sectors represent 4% and 29.8% of our energy holdings, respectively, and had a net unrealized loss of $114.9 million as of year-end.
The remaining 2/3 of our energy holdings are in midstream companies, integrated oil companies and the refiners. These holdings are much less sensitive to oil prices, and have a net unrealized gain of $63.5 million at year-end. Our exposure to below investment grade energy credits declined slightly in the quarter to 14 .1% of the energy holdings, compared to 14.8% at the end of the third quarter.
Approximately 3/4 of the below investment grade exposure is the more highly rated BB category. Realized losses in energy holdings from both losses on sales and from impairments were $20.1 million for the fourth quarter.
energy holdings and look at a number stressed scenarios. While downgrade of holdings and some impairments may have over time, we feel the impacts are very manageable and did not alter our financial per capital plans. 
Moving to capital management. We continue to see very favorable trends. We repurchased the $100 million of stock this quarter, bringing the total repurchases to $427 million in full year 2015, which is a approximately 4.9% of our year ends 2014 outstanding shares. We estimate, we close the year with a weighted average risk base capital ratio for our traditional U.S. life insurance companies at approximately 400%, consistent with the levels we held throughout the year, and towards the higher end of our expected range for the year. Holding company cash and marketable securities was $475 million at year end, and statutory operating and comes were $182.4 million for the fourth quarter and $689.2 million for full year 2015, a strong sales level of earnings and 11.5% increase over 2014.
Finally, I'll note that our tax rate for the fourth quarter was 28.5% was favorable relative to the 30.9% rate that we recorded for the first three quarters in the year. This was primarily driven by reduction in deferred tax liability related to our U.K. operations as a result of the enactment of future reductions in the U.K. tax rates, and also the benefit of the extension of active financing in the fourth quarter that reversed the tax expense we recorded in the third quarter.
Wrapping up, our expectation for after-tax operating income per share for 2016 is not changed from what we previously discussed at our outlook meeting at December. We did finish 2015 with a higher level of income than we had anticipated, so the growth rate for 2016 of the $3.64 of 2015 operating income per share, is expected to be within a range of 3% to 6%. So, overall, it was a very good fourth quarter and a very strong full year performance for the company. Now, I'll turn things back to Rick for his closing comments.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Jack. Just to wrap up before we go on to your question. I'll reiterate from a company operating perspective, it was a very good quarter and year for our company. We have seen the resumption of top line growth for our core businesses, and do
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Jack. Just to wrap up before we go on to your question. I'll reiterate from a company operating perspective, it was a very good quarter and year for our company. We have seen the resumption of top line growth for our core businesses, and done so without sacrificing our profitability. Our statutory earnings are strong, which helps generate capital to not only maintain a very healthy balance sheet for troubling macro environment, but also flexibility to grow and also return capital to our shareholders. This does very well, as we move into 2016. We will move now on to your questions. So I will ask to begin the question-and-answer session. Cynthia?

componenttext: In supplemental and voluntary, the benefit ratios were a little bit higher than running recently, and then documentation was lower. Can you talk about what drove those two things, and if they were related to each other?

componenttext: There is some relationship, particularly in the voluntary benefits lines. Some of the products within those lines have active life reserves. And so, those policies terminate, you release the active life results and you're write off the associated with them. Actually, our persistency was a little better, particularly in those product lines that have those active life reserves, and so that resulted in a little bit higher loss ratio and a little bit slower amortization of the balance. And net-net, the earnings impact was very minimal.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Rick, a bit of a philosophical question for you. I find it kind of staggering, I guess, the market is somewhere around 10% off of it, it's all-time highs, and yet Unum's shares are trading 30%, 35% below your 52-week high, ended a sort of stagger
componenttext: I guess, Rick, a bit of a philosophical question for you. I find it kind of staggering, I guess, the market is somewhere around 10% off of it, it's all-time highs, and yet Unum's shares are trading 30%, 35% below your 52-week high, ended a sort of staggering discount to book value per share at Just curious, how you think about the pace of capital management, in particular, when you think about a 400% risk-based capital ratio relative to your business mix? And coming off of a very strong year, statutory operating income in 2015?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, John. Just to give me some perspective on that. I think, one of the things bring you back to you very quickly though is, we operate this company the same every we've been operating at very consistent. We're going growing the company now. Margins are
componenttext: Sure, John. Just to give me some perspective on that. I think, one of the things bring you back to you very quickly though is, we operate this company the same every we've been operating at very consistent. We're going growing the company now. Margins are still very good. We as a team here, are focused very much on that. In terms of was going on in the market around us, so there's a lot of things out there in the news, continued lower interest rate environment, questions about the economy, there are so many things that impact our stock price. We try not to focus on that from a operator perspective. What it does actually meet up with how we think about managing the capital of the company is, we are buying back our shares and have been doing so for the last several years. So when you look at that, you think about, where we are buying back shares today relative to where we were even in the fourth quarter and over the average of the year, and how does that impact our thinking. And when I this gets to your philosophical point is, we actually on that front, stay very consistent as well. So we think about ourselves as a steady returner of capital to our shareholders. We will buy a little bit more when prices are down and a little bit less when the prices are up. But consistency of return is something that we focus on as they general philosophy of the company, but also with regard to the capital management. So as we look at where our share price is today, we will be buying a lot more shares, in terms of the actual dollars that we're putting out, you probably see a pretty consistent levels to what we've done in the past.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

And as a result of that, our steady operating performance say, that will pretty steady in terms of returning capital as well.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. First would be -- you are right. It is an important date for us. On the renewal front, good news there. So persistency is in line with what our expectations are. That's great. That's the big driver of the top line. But also as you know, we've been p
componenttext: Sure. First would be -- you are right. It is an important date for us. On the renewal front, good news there. So persistency is in line with what our expectations are. That's great. That's the big driver of the top line. But also as you know, we've been putting gradual price increases into the market about every 6 months over the last 18 to 24 months. So sticky business is always good, but particularly, when you're gradually increasing rates, particularly in group insurance to account for the lower interest rate environment that we talked about. So feel good about that. On the new business front, you sort of see a slight decline in sales this year, go down about 3% in the fourth quarter, but as both Rick and Jack highlighted, actually 4Q came in right in line with our expectations. We faced a really difficult comp, up 25% a year ago. So good to finish for the full year, right out of just over the top of the range we laid out to you guys at the beginning of the year.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttextpreview: So, we've seen reductions and we've seen the interest rates fall since the year end. This is very similar to what happened last year, actually too during this period. It doesn't mean that they are going to stay there for the full year. We've also said --
componenttext: So, we've seen reductions and we've seen the interest rates fall since the year end. This is very similar to what happened last year, actually too during this period. It doesn't mean that they are going to stay there for the full year. We've also said -- seen spreads widening. I'll pull you back to the fourth quarter,  where we're actually -- our new money rates were higher than we've seen in quarter while and we're supporting about our reserve assumptions in both disability lines as well as long-term care lines. We keep track of that. We keep raising rates in response to the lower interest environment. We look for opportunities to book money to work at good yields. It something we look at during the year. I would say that we're pretty comfortable. But right now that relative to 2015, that we won't to forced to  take a action because we have a good margin, interest margin now in our reserve. But it something that we continue to look at and decide, as we do our reserve for this year.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, on long-term care, obviously, rates are challenging, but how are the other things going, like claims trends, your success in achieving price hikes versus what you might when you took the reserve charge in the fourth quarter of 2014?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: I think, unlike -- you mentioned the word unlock, and this is not an unlock. So when you look at it, this is not -- also not a mean reversion. So this is a view on path of interest rate. Over a 10-year period of time, and as Jack said, that's an outlook that we had last year, going through the process, and it really hasn't changed as of now. And so it's not something that we look at a mean reversion, as you think about the traditional method.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then, just jumping over to credit side. Is there any update, the disclosure at of your energy exposure is very good relative to your peers, so we appreciate that. And as you mentioned in your opening remarks, loss really is not that big, at least as of year end. I'll be interested in any update kind of on what year-to-date activity look like there from an unrealized position in if there's been any action by Unum to derisk energy or any other credits that are moving out or if conversely, you're seeing this maybe an opportunity to add more wider spreads?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we certainly not starting with the last thing first. We're not viewing this as an opportunity to add more wider spread. We always actively manage our portfolio. So we're a credit chop. We're looking at our energy things. Spreads have widening since y
componenttext: Yes, we certainly not starting with the last thing first. We're not viewing this as an opportunity to add more wider spread. We always actively manage our portfolio. So we're a credit chop. We're looking at our energy things. Spreads have widening since year end. So that capital -- that unrealized loss would be somewhat bigger. We don't -- we haven't fully valued the portfolio as yet. So we don't know the what the size of that is. But again, probably the important thing to note is, we are all over our energy portfolio. We looked at, we stress tested it under a number of different scenarios. When we look at it, we consider both the realized losses that we may have to take as well as the RBC impact of any downgrades that we would foresee. And because of the strong financial position we go into 2016 with we view this as a very manageable issue for us. There is nothing we see right now, that would change our outlook for capital plans for 2016.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, it's driven by two things:. One of the big ones is spreads widen. And although the yield curve is flattened at that front end, it's still stayed pretty steady at the long end of the spread between the 10-year and the 30-year is still in that 75 t
componenttext: I think, it's driven by two things:. One of the big ones is spreads widen. And although the yield curve is flattened at that front end, it's still stayed pretty steady at the long end of the spread between the 10-year and the 30-year is still in that 75 to 85 basis points range. So when you invest in longer maturities, which as a result of some of the M&A activity, there is a lot more launches available. And you put the widened spreads on top of those, you get up above the 5% range to the end of the year. There is also alternative investments, we put a portion of the portfolio that continued to put a portion into high yield, where spreads have widened as well.

componenttext: Yes, sure. So we've seen a bit of consolidation with a few names mid-sized coming together and/or being international player. I wouldn't say that, that has led to a significant disruption. So if you look at things like again the renewal rates for us have been right in line to slightly favorable, I think the proposal activity has been generally in line with what we've seen across this segment. So not big disruption I would point to. But I do think, if you think about the market in general, there is sort of the capabilities that are offered. And we have seen a few new entrants into the market. But the good news for us is, capabilities in terms of the process, the technology and the people they take  have substantial amount of time to build. So we feel pretty good about the head-start we have there. But pricing environment, just to give you some color, I'd say is pretty typical. We got a few that are heavy step back and repriced to improve margins. And then we've got a few they are probably leaving a bit more into growing their books, and I think that kind of balances out to pretty typical pricing environment.

componenttext: Technical question here and thinking about the portfolio. Is it well, should the level at which they are trading below fair value or is there certain time just you can give us some help in terms of thinking about, when you would take such a charge?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jack, do you want to share your views on that?
componenttext: Jack, do you want to share your views on that?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There is no hard and fast rules around when you would recognize an impairment, but there are some guidelines. And we consider four things. The first is, is the money good. Do we believe that we're going to get principal and interest payments out of i
componenttext: Yes. There is no hard and fast rules around when you would recognize an impairment, but there are some guidelines. And we consider four things. The first is, is the money good. Do we believe that we're going to get principal and interest payments out of it. The second thing we'll consider is, do we intend to hold it to recovery. And so if we do, that would keep it at book value. The third thing you consider it, are they current on interest an principle payments. And then beyond that, it tends to be a security by security analysis. It's a judgment about whether we believe over time, this will recover and be money good. And so there's no hard and fast rules. We work with our investment to We work with our auditors and we come to judgments on the securities.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Great. And then, switching gears, thinking about the environment for rate increases and long-term care. It sounded like came in sort of line with your expeditions. componenttext: Yes, I think, we continue to see a positive tone from regulators. It certainly, better today than it was 3 or 4 years ago. Even some of the, kind of states like New York are seem to be coming along and considering rate increases in a different given the environment. So I think it continues to get better over time.

componenttext: Jack, in the Investor Day you held back in December, I was really interested in the whole discussion about, how the Closed Block of individual disability business increasingly looking like a lifetime annuity. And I was also very interested in the that you drew in the risk characteristics of your group LTC business that is closed versus your individual business. My inference was that, may be these businesses could be salable, reinsurable, that somehow you could free up the capital this year. Was that the right inference? The answer on that. And was that the right inference. And it was the right inference, what would be the process that you would follow this year to move forward on that front?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Clearly, looking at capital management opportunities on both of those blocks, is something that as we actively do and consistently. Whether those opportunities can actually come to this year, it would be really hard to say. So it's we look at, and we're in constant communications with alternative sources of capital. But being able to predict whether something will actually happen or not, would be beyond what I can do.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could just ask one follow-up question, that would either to Rick. Quick, if you are -- if the company is as flexible and as opportunistic as you say it is, if you have the capital spread to be flexible and opportunistic, then why wouldn't you,
componenttext: Okay. If I could just ask one follow-up question, that would either to Rick. Quick, if you are -- if the company is as flexible and as opportunistic as you say it is, if you have the capital spread to be flexible and opportunistic, then why wouldn't you, going back to John's question, why wouldn't you do with the stock price where it is, step up your dollar amounts of share repurchase to take advantage of this opportunity?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is a fair question, Eric. I think you get back to the pace at which we're doing that. We do have flexibility. We could do that if we so choose, but it comes back to the philosophy we have in the company around, as we generate the capital, we're going
componenttext: That is a fair question, Eric. I think you get back to the pace at which we're doing that. We do have flexibility. We could do that if we so choose, but it comes back to the philosophy we have in the company around, as we generate the capital, we're going to return it to the shareholders. Some of the excess capital positions we hold, we think about using on how we can deploy that to grow the company in different areas. And so it's been much more on that philosophy. Yes, we've been doing now the yield back for the last 7 years. And so over that period of time, we've seen our stock price move up and down. Oftentimes not related to what's going on in the company. And so we've taken advantage of some low stock prices, and at the same time we brought back shares when we were at a higher prices. And so now I think now is the right time to pile in, to buying a whole lot of share, I think that's for our company. We are much more disciplined, much more consistent in how we look at things.

Just want to get a sense of how we should about that number, is it a binding at all? Any guidance would be helpful.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure Sumeet. This is Rick. I'm not sure it's philosophical. When we think about the capital allocation to our Closed Block, that's not we want to be putting our capital today. So the numbers you see here today are higher than we want to be. And I think ge
componenttext: Sure Sumeet. This is Rick. I'm not sure it's philosophical. When we think about the capital allocation to our Closed Block, that's not we want to be putting our capital today. So the numbers you see here today are higher than we want to be. And I think gets back to the question that Jack was answering, is how do we free up that capital? How do we reduce the capital buying those lines of business, so we can continue to do what we've been doing in more capital to our operating companies. But also on position that we're generating enough capital as a company that our business lines, our main operating companies are getting the capital -- getting all the capital that they need to continue to generate growth. I think the -- only constrain is more in the market in making sure that it's good profitable growth as opposed to the amount of capital we can put behind it. So as we tell everyone inside the companies, we want to funnel as much capital as we possibly can to continue to grow our lines of business. And what we haven't found, is actually a shortfall to do so. And that's one of the reason we're buying back a lot of stock is because we actually can't put as much capital sa we want to behind our growing lines that are generating very high returns. So back to your original question, I think that the capital allocating to our Closed Block is one we want to reduce over time. And as we talked about in different settings, that is something we're actively working on as a company.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: First question just on long-term care. So the interest adjusted loss ratio is in the high 80s. And I know that high end of the band that you all have looked at. Can you help us think about the numbers, the interest adjusted loss ratio and then potentially additions to reserves?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: I would say that it's lot more complicated than that. The reserve basis of long-term care is very detailed. There is a lot of sensitive into play. I was thinking guidance, that if you were about 90% for long period of time, that would be an indication of pressure on the reserves. But it wouldn't react to one or two quarters in that range. And it would really depend long-term on what the factors were that were driving you above 90.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Clearly, the spreads have widened in the energy sector since year end. So that $370 million would be wider. We don't have -- we do monthly evaluations on most of the bonds in our portfolio. That's not complete right now, and so we don't have a numbe
componenttext: Okay. Clearly, the spreads have widened in the energy sector since year end. So that $370 million would be wider. We don't have -- we do monthly evaluations on most of the bonds in our portfolio. That's not complete right now, and so we don't have a number for you that we can share. With respect to what we look at, again, I will bring you back to the first one we look at, is the money good? Do we tend to hold it through recovery? And then, are they current with interest and principal payments? You talked about the review of bonds that are under a certain percent of market to book. The fact of the matter in our energy portfolio today. we are constantly reviewing those bonds. We're looking at all the high-yield bonds. We are looking at those bonds on a ongoing basis and actively working to manage through this. So I don't think there is anything special about bonds, necessarily by trading relative to book because we're looking at that entire portfolio on a constant basis.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just as a follow-up on that, I thought the concept of OTTI was that, even if bonds money are money good, but it's the term and to be trading at an impaired level on a permanent basis. That's where bonds are impaired, at least from a GAAP accounting standp
componenttext: Just as a follow-up on that, I thought the concept of OTTI was that, even if bonds money are money good, but it's the term and to be trading at an impaired level on a permanent basis. That's where bonds are impaired, at least from a GAAP accounting standpoint. That sort of what I was getting at, from the standpoint of not so much you writing it down from a statutory standpoint, but a GAAP standpoint, the concept of OTTI is a price-driven concept, not a loss concept, if you know, what I mean?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our view is, it's not a bright line loss-driven concept. The big question that as you said, is it temporary or not? And so the question we have is, do we expect it to -- if it's money good, it's going to recover. So ultimately it's going to pay off an
componenttext: And our view is, it's not a bright line loss-driven concept. The big question that as you said, is it temporary or not? And so the question we have is, do we expect it to -- if it's money good, it's going to recover. So ultimately it's going to pay off and you will get all your proceeds. And so again it comes back to those things. Is the money good? Do we intend to hold it? Is it coming? And clearly, the longer and lower it trades, kind of the more pressure and the more work you need to do to demonstrate that those first 3 are actually true and believable. But it is not a bright line issue.

componenttext: Just the post the question on sensitivity to capital on the investment portfolio. headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I can give you a couple of things to you. One is, if we look at the portfolio and we said, if every single bond in our energy report was downgraded a single notch, so be BAA2 went to BAA3, and BAA3 went to BB, what would the impact be. That's a 4-po
componenttext: Okay. I can give you a couple of things to you. One is, if we look at the portfolio and we said, if every single bond in our energy report was downgraded a single notch, so be BAA2 went to BAA3, and BAA3 went to BB, what would the impact be. That's a 4-point impact on our risk-based capital. The second point I'd to give you, if everything dropped a full letter, so all our BBBs went to BBs, all of our As went to triple BBB. That would be a 15 point impact to our risk-based capital. It's -- capital leading impact on risk-based capital is more than just looking at the change in the RBC factors because C1 capital gets cash affected, and so that reduces the burden. There's also significant diversification benefit with C1 capital that further reduces the impact relative to those numbers. So something that we really need to work through. But it's far less of an impact than just looking at the change in the percent capital holdings applying them by a 3.5.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Unum Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the conference over to the Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tom White. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Cynthia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call for Unum. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact. As a r
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Cynthia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call for Unum. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact. As a result, actual results might differ materially from these results suggested by these forward-looking statements. Information concerning factors that could cause results to differ appears in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and are also located in the section titled Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-looking Statements and risk factors in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2014, and our subsequently filed quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. Our SEC filings can be found in the Investors section of our website at www.unum.com.
I'll remind you that the statements in today's call speak only of the date they are made, and we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements.
As we discuss our financial results this quarter, I'll remind you that our prior-period results have been adjusted for our retrospective adoption of the accounting standards, update for tax credit partnership investments and qualified affordable housing projects. Adjusted prior-period results are available on our website in a supplemental exhibit.
A presentation of the most directly comparable GAAP measures and reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures included in today's presentation can be found in our statistical supplement on our website, also in the Investors section.
So participating in morning's conference call are Unum's President and CEO, Rick McKenney; CFO, Jack McGarry; as well as the CEOs of our core business segments: Mike Simonds for Unum US; Peter O'Donnell for Unum UK; and Tim Arnold for Colonial Life. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. We finished 2015 on a strong note with fourth quarter operating income at $0.95 per share. That's an increase of 6.7% over last year, bringing the full year EPS to $3.64, whic
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. We finished 2015 on a strong note with fourth quarter operating income at $0.95 per share. That's an increase of 6.7% over last year, bringing the full year EPS to $3.64, which is an increase of 3.7%. We ended the year in the middle of our outlook range of 2% to 5%, which we're tracking to all year. I'm especially pleased with the balanced performance we continue to show on our core business segments. With good levels of premium growth, complemented by stable benefits experienced across all lines, this combination helps to drive strong profit margins and excellent capital generation for the company.
Our financial flexibility continues to be an important asset to us as we move into 2016, as we look to take advantage of the opportunities for profitable growth and to expand our leadership positions in the employee and voluntary benefits markets.
I will cover a few highlights for the fourth quarter, and then Jack will provide an analysis of our results in greater detail. I'll start with premium growth in our core business segments, which continue at a healthy and well-balanced pace. For the fourth quarter, premiums in each of our 3 core segments, Unum US, Unum UK and Colonial Life, all increased by more than 5%. For Unum US, fourth quarter sales had a difficult comparison given the 25% jump we saw in the year-ago fourth quarter. But for the full year 2015, we generated an increase of just over 4%, at the top end of our expectations coming into 2015.
In addition, Unum US persistency trends remain favorable, and our ongoing focus on renewals helped drive the 5.5% increase in premium income. Unum UK sales in local currency improved in the fourth quarter with growth of 11%, driven largely by strong results in the core market long-term disability sales and large case Group Life sales. Combined with improving persistency and the benefit of a recently acquired dental business, Unum UK generated 5% growth in premiums in the fourth quarter as well. 
Finally, at Colonial Life, sales growth continues to be quite encouraging, increasing 5% for the fourth quarter and almost 7% for the full year, helping to generate premium growth of just over 5% for the quarter.
Next, it's important that we've not sacrificed the profitability of our core businesses to generate this premium growth, as our benefits experience has remained stable across all 3 business segments. In fact, the benefit ratios for the 3 core business segments improved for the full year 2015 relative to 2014.
Jack will provide additional detail on these trends in his commentary. Given these operating results, we continue to produce a very strong level of capital, which provides us substantial financial flexibility. This flexibility allows us to fund the capital required to grow our business, while also returning capital to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends as we brought back $427 million of stock in 2015. In addition, we've continued to grow our book value per share with book value now at $35.90, an increase of 8.4% for the year, consistent with the growth we have generated since 2008. 
And finally, the macro environment, including the ongoing low interest rate environment, continues to present challenges. Interest rates and investment spreads remain below historical levels and below our portfolio yields. Our focus remains on actively managing through this environment by steadily taking pricing actions. But in the near term, it does continue to dampen our profit growth. 
So with these highlights on our fourth quarter performance, I'll have Jack cover our results in greater detail. Jack?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Rick provided a high-level overview of our fourth quarter results, and now I want provide a more in-depth view of the operating and business trends we saw in the quarter. I'll begin with Unum US, where fourth q
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Rick provided a high-level overview of our fourth quarter results, and now I want provide a more in-depth view of the operating and business trends we saw in the quarter. I'll begin with Unum US, where fourth quarter operating income was $214.2 million, an increase of 2.2% from the year-ago quarter of $209.5 million. Premium income growth remains very healthy, increasing 5.5% over the year-ago quarter, while the benefit ratio for Unum US segment improves slightly to 71.1% in the quarter compared to 71.3% in the year-ago quarter.
The profitability of Unum US remained strong with an operating ROE of 13.1% for the fourth quarter, and 13.3% for the full year. Within the Unum US segment, operating income in our core -- in our group disability business was $66.1 million, an increase of 0.3% from the year-ago quarter of $65.9 million. Premium income increased 5.5% over the year-ago quarter. But we continue to see pressure on net investment income, which declined by 5.7% compared to the year-ago quarter, driven by lower asset levels, lower portfolio yield and lower miscellaneous investment income.
Benefits experience improved in the fourth quarter relative to the year-ago quarter. The benefit ratio was 81.7% for the fourth quarter compared to 83.7% a year ago, driven primarily by lower claims incidence rates and favorable claim recovery experience in our group long-term disability product line as well as favorable benefits experienced in our group short-term disability line.
Group Life and AD&D operating income was $54.3 million for the fourth quarter, a decline of 8.4% from the year-ago quarter. Premium income continues to grow at a favorable level, increasing 5.2% over the year-ago quarter. The benefit ratio was 72% for the fourth quarter compared to 70.8% in the year-ago quarter due to a higher average paid claim size for both the Group Life line and the AD&D line of business. While the benefit ratio was higher on a year-over-year basis, the fourth quarter experience was generally consistent with the 71.8% benefit ratio for the full year 2015.
Operating income in the supplemental and voluntary lines was very strong at $93.8 million in the fourth quarter, an increase of 11.3% compared to $84.3 million in the year-ago quarter. Premium income growth trends were also strong for this line of business, increasing 5.7% in the quarter compared to last year.
From the benefits perspective, results were in line with our expectation. The fourth quarter benefit ratio for the individual disability line was 33.8% on an interest-adjusted basis and 48% for the voluntary benefits line.
Looking at Unum UK, operating income was a GBP 24.4 million for the fourth quarter, an increase of 1.2% over the year-ago quarter of GBP 24.1 million. The benefit ratio was 69.9% for the fourth quarter compared to 68.8% in the year-ago quarter, driven primarily by higher claim incidence trends in the group long-term disability and Group Life lines of business, which were approximately offset by improved claim recoveries. Overall, profitability of the UK segment remains quite favorable with an operating ROE of 20.6% for the fourth quarter and 18% for the full year.
Colonial Life continues to generate strong consistent results with operating income of $77.6 million, up 4.9% increase over the year-ago quarter of $74 million. The benefit ratio improved to 51.2% for the fourth quarter compared to 52.3% for the year-ago quarter, driven by favorable benefits experienced in the accident, sickness and disability product line. Margins remain strong for Colonial Life with an operating ROE of 16.4% this quarter and 16.6% for the full year.
Finally, for the Closed Block, operating income was $28.1 million in the fourth quarter compared to $29.4 million in the year-ago quarter, excluding the 2014 long-term care reserve charge. The benefits experienced for the individual disability line was in line with our expectations. The increase in the interest-adjusted loss ratio to 87.2% in the fourth quarter compared to 81% in the year-ago quarter was largely driven by a reduction in the reserve discount rate to recognize the impact on future portfolio yields from the higher-than-normal level of miscellaneous net investment income. 
For the long-term care line, the interest-adjusted loss ratio was 89.7% for the fourth quarter compared to 89.6% for the year-ago quarter, excluding the reserve charge.
The underlying risk experienced for long-term care was consistent with our long-term expectations for the full year 2015 interest-adjusted loss ratio of 87.6%, within our expected range of 85% to 90%. 
Regarding the reserve position for long-term care, we feel good about where we finished 2015 in terms of reserve adequacy. For the year, our new money yields exceeded all and remained within our long-term expectations. In addition, rate increase approvals and implementation are tracking in line with our reserve assumptions. One additional comment on long-term care, the cash flow testing reserve addition we recorded for our New York subsidiary, First Unum, was $68 million at year-end 2015. I'll now move to the growth trends we experienced across the company in the quarter.
Again, starting with Unum US, total sales declined by 3.7% for the fourth quarter compared to a year ago. This was not unexpected as we had very strong sales results from the year-ago fourth quarter, and we continue to increase rates during the year. For the full year, Unum US sales increased by 4.2%, which was slightly above the top end of our expectation of 2% to 4% growth. 
Looking at the sales results by product line, LTD sales were flat in the fourth quarter, but increased 7.2% for the full year. STD sales declined by 20% for the fourth quarter, but grew slightly for the full year, increasing by 0.8%. At Group Life and AD&D, sales declined 2.5% for the quarter and 5.6% for the full year. Also within Unum US, we had strong sales results in individual disability for the fourth quarter, increasing 30.4% to $21 million, driven by success with large case enrollment. 
Full-year sales growth for the individual disability line was 18.8%. Finally, in the voluntary benefits product line, total sales declined 7.4% for the fourth quarter. Core market voluntary benefit sales showed very good growth, while large case sales were lower against a very strong large case quarter last year.
Full year 2015 sales and voluntary benefits increased 10.3% with good balance between the core market and large case sales. Our sales outlook for 2016 for Unum US calls for growth rate in the 2% to 4% range again. It's likely that we'll see quarterly volatility as we did in 2015, particularly given the volatility of timing of large case sales.
Persistency for Unum US continues at healthy levels. For the group lines combined, persistency was 90.3% for the full year 2015, which was stable with the 90.5% for 2014. Given these sales trends and persistency levels, along with the underlying management of enforced renewals, we generated premium income growth for Unum US this quarter of 5.5%. Full year premium growth was 6.4%, consistent with our long-term outlook for this segment and our strongest rate of growth in many years.
Sales in Unum UK rebounded nicely in the fourth quarter, increasing 11.2% in local currency, with favorable trends in the core market group long-term disability product line and in Group Life. For the full year, sales grew by 6.2%. Persistency in the group disability line was 89.2% for the full year of 2015, off slightly from 2014 levels, but in line with our expectations.
Persistency for the Group Life line continue to recover at 80% for full year 2015, up from 76% in 2014. Premium income growth for the U.K. this quarter was 5.4% in local currency, including the impact of the acquisition of the dental business in the third quarter, and 2.3% for full year above our expectations of 0% to 2% growth.
Finally, Colonial Life sales remain on a positive trend, increasing 5.1% for the fourth quarter and 6.9% for the full year. Growth this quarter was again well-balanced between the commercial market sector, both core market sales and large case sales in the public sector. In addition, each product lines showed positive year-over-year growth. Persistency for Colonial Life was slightly lower for the year at 78.5% compared to 79.4% for 2014. But premium growth continues to show good momentum, increasing 5.1% in the fourth quarter compared to the year-ago quarter. Full year premium growth was also 5.1% well above the top end of our expectation of 2% to 4% growth.
Overall, we remain very pleased with the growth trends we see in our core business segments as well as the profit margins we are maintaining.
Looking now at investment results. New, money yields were slightly better in the fourth quarter compared to the first 9 months of 2015. However, today's new money yields remain below our current portfolio yield, so the downward pressure on our portfolio yields and net investment income continues to impact our profitability. We're actively raising prices in our markets to help manage this impact. The credit quality of our investment portfolio remains in very good shape. Our overall default experience relative to the Moody's index was again very favorable at 15 basis points for full year 2015 compared to 80 basis points for the index. 
I'd like to give you an update on our energy-related holdings, which totaled $5 billion or 11.6% of our total fixed maturity securities at year-end 2015.
The severe widening of credit spreads in the energy sector during the fourth quarter reduced the net unrealized gain from $302.8 million as of September 30, 2015 to a net unrealized loss of $51.4 million at December 31, 2015.
We saw relatively more spread widening in the oilfield services and independent oil and gas sectors of our portfolio. As we discussed with you at our outlook meeting in December, these sectors tend to be the most sensitive companies to oil prices. The sectors represent 4% and 29.8% of our energy holdings, respectively, and had a net unrealized loss of $114.9 million as of year-end.
The remaining 2/3 of our energy holdings are in midstream companies, integrated oil companies and refiners. These holdings are much less sensitive to oil prices and have a net unrealized gain of $63.5 million at year-end. Our exposure to below-investment grade energy credits declined slightly in the quarter to 14.1% of the energy holdings compared to 14.8% at the end of the third quarter.
Approximately 3/4 of the below-investment grade exposure is the more highly rated BB category. Realized losses in energy holdings from both losses on sales and from impairments were $20.1 million pretax for the fourth quarter.
We have thoroughly reviewed our energy holdings and looked at a number of stress scenarios. While downgrade of holdings and some impairments may happen over time, we feel the impacts are very manageable and did not alter our financial per capital plans. 
Moving to capital management. We continue to see very favorable trends. We repurchased the $100 million of our stock this quarter, bringing the total repurchases to $427 million in full year 2015, which is approximately 4.9% of our year-end 2014 outstanding shares. We estimate we close the year with a weighted average risk-based capital ratio for our traditional U.S. life insurance companies at approximately 400%, consistent with the levels we've held throughout the year and towards the higher end of our expected range for the year. Holding company cash and marketable securities was $475 million at year-end, and statutory operating earnings were $182.4 million for the fourth quarter and $689.2 million for full year 2015, a strong sales level of earnings and an 11.5% increase over 2014.
Finally, I'll note our tax rate in the fourth quarter of 28.5% was favorable relative to the 30.9% rate that we recorded for the first three quarters of the year. This was primarily driven by a reduction in deferred tax liability related to our U.K. operations as a result of the enactment of future reductions in the U.K. tax rate and also the benefit of the extension of active financing in the fourth quarter that reversed the tax expense we recorded in the third quarter.
Wrapping up, our expectation for after-tax operating income per share for 2016 has not changed from what we've previously discussed at our outlook meeting in December. We did finish 2015 with a higher level of income than we had anticipated. So the growth rate for 2016 of $3.64 of 2015 operating income per share is expected to be within a range of 3% to 6%. So overall, it was a very good fourth quarter and a very strong full year performance for the company. Now I'll turn things back to Rick for his closing comments.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Jack. And just to wrap up before we go on to your questions, I'll reiterate, from a company operating perspective, it was a very good quarter and year for our company. We've seen the resumption of top line growth for our core businesses and
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Jack. And just to wrap up before we go on to your questions, I'll reiterate, from a company operating perspective, it was a very good quarter and year for our company. We've seen the resumption of top line growth for our core businesses and done so without sacrificing our profitability. Our statutory earnings are strong, which helps generate capital to not only maintain a very healthy balance sheet for a troubling macro environment, but also flexibility to grow and also return capital to our shareholders. This all positions us very well as we move into 2016. We'll move now on to your questions, so I'll ask Cynthia to begin the question-and-answer session. Cynthia?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ryan Krueger from KBW.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: In supplemental and voluntary, the benefit ratios were a little bit higher than they've been running recently, and then DAC amortization was lower. Can you talk about what drove those 2 things, and if they were related to each other?
componenttext: In supplemental and voluntary, the benefit ratios were a little bit higher than they've been running recently, and then DAC amortization was lower. Can you talk about what drove those 2 things, and if they were related to each other?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is some relations, particularly in the voluntary benefit lines, that some of the products within those lines have active life reserves. And so if those policies terminate, you release the active life reserve and you're write out the DAC associated w
componenttext: There is some relations, particularly in the voluntary benefit lines, that some of the products within those lines have active life reserves. And so if those policies terminate, you release the active life reserve and you're write out the DAC associated with them. Actually, our persistency was a little better, particularly in those product lines that have those active life reserves. And so that resulted in a little bit higher loss ratio and a little bit slower amortization of the DAC balance. And net-net, the earnings impact was very minimal.

componenttext: Jack , you want to take that?

componenttext: Yes, thanks. So as we told you -- actually, it's been a year ago now, in the fourth quarter of 2014, we'd assumed that interest rates would stay level with the rate they were at, somewhere around the 5% range all in for the next 5 years, and then would gradually revert to a long-term average over the subsequent 5 years.

componenttext: I mean, it's hard to tell with -- treasury yields have clearly gone down over the last couple of weeks. Spreads have widened since the end of the year, so I wouldn't have a spot rate for you.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we have John Nadel from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And next we have John Nadel from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Rick, a bit of a philosophical question for you. I find it kind of staggering. I guess, the market is somewhere around 10% off of its all-time highs, and yet Unum's shares are trading to 30%, 35% below your 52-week high and a sort of staggering d
componenttext: I guess, Rick, a bit of a philosophical question for you. I find it kind of staggering. I guess, the market is somewhere around 10% off of its all-time highs, and yet Unum's shares are trading to 30%, 35% below your 52-week high and a sort of staggering discount to book value per share. Just curious how you think about the pace of capital management, in particular when you think about a 400% risk-based capital ratio relative to your business mix and coming off of a very strong year of statutory operating income in 2015.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, John. Just to give me some perspectives on that. I think that one of the things that I'd bring you back to very quickly, though, is we operate this company the same way we've been operating it very consistent. We're going growing the company now. Ma
componenttext: Sure, John. Just to give me some perspectives on that. I think that one of the things that I'd bring you back to very quickly, though, is we operate this company the same way we've been operating it very consistent. We're going growing the company now. Margins are still very good. And we, as a team here, are focused very much on that. In terms of what's going on in the market around us, so there's a lot of things out there in the news, continued lower interest rate environment, questions about the economy, there's so many things that impact our stock price, we try not to focus on that from an operating perspective. Where it does actually meet up with how we think about managing the capital of the company is we are buying back our shares and have been doing so for the last several years. So when you look at that, you think about where we're buying back shares today relative to where we were even in the fourth quarter and for over the average of the year and how does it impact our thinking. And what I take you to, this gets to your philosophical point, is we actually, on that front, stay very consistent as well. So we think about it ourselves as a steady returner of capital to our shareholders. We'll buy a little bit more when prices are down and a little bit less when prices are up. But consistency of return is something that we focus on as a general philosophy of the company, but also with regards to capital management. So as we look at where our share price is today, we'll be buying a lot more shares. In terms of the actual dollars that we're putting out, you'll probably see a pretty consistent levels to what we've done in the past.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So no significant -- if we think about it relative to you outlook for 2016, I think you had formerly indicated that the dollar amount of buybacks would probably be pretty similar to the level spent in 2015. No significant adjustment there then, Rick
componenttext: Okay. So no significant -- if we think about it relative to you outlook for 2016, I think you had formerly indicated that the dollar amount of buybacks would probably be pretty similar to the level spent in 2015. No significant adjustment there then, Rick?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's probably fair. And when you think about it, we're buying back shares with the capital, with free capital we generated. So this isn't something other than as we generate that capital, which we've done so very consistently, we're returning th
componenttext: I think that's probably fair. And when you think about it, we're buying back shares with the capital, with free capital we generated. So this isn't something other than as we generate that capital, which we've done so very consistently, we're returning that to our shareholders through share repurchase. And as a result of that, our steady operating performance would say that will be pretty steady in terms of returning capital as well.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Okay. And then a quick one on the tax rate, just is there any implication as you look out to 2016, Jack, as a result of the U.K. adjustment? Or do we stick with the 31% to 32% range that I think you guys have expected for this year?
componenttext: Understood. Okay. And then a quick one on the tax rate, just is there any implication as you look out to 2016, Jack, as a result of the U.K. adjustment? Or do we stick with the 31% to 32% range that I think you guys have expected for this year?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that 31% to 32% range, that was kind of a onetime shift, that it's not going to really move the needle that much going forward.
componenttext: No. I think that 31% to 32% range, that was kind of a onetime shift, that it's not going to really move the needle that much going forward.

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then last one is maybe for Mike, and that's just a question about January 1, a very important, obviously, sales and retention period, any color you can offer as to what's going on in the U.S. market there?
componenttext: And then last one is maybe for Mike, and that's just a question about January 1, a very important, obviously, sales and retention period, any color you can offer as to what's going on in the U.S. market there?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Thanks, John. So first would be, you're right. It is an important date for us. On the renewal front, good news there. So persistency is in line with what our expectations are. That's great. That's a big driver of the top line. But also, as you
componenttext: Yes, sure. Thanks, John. So first would be, you're right. It is an important date for us. On the renewal front, good news there. So persistency is in line with what our expectations are. That's great. That's a big driver of the top line. But also, as you know, we've been putting gradual price increases into the market about every 6 months over the last 18 to 24 months. So sticky business is always good, but particularly when you're gradually increasing rates, particularly in group insurance to account for the low interest rate environment that we talked about. So I feel good about that. On the new business front, you'd sort of see a slight decline in sales this year. I think we're down about 3% in the fourth quarter. But as both Rick and Jack highlighted, actually, 4Q came in right in line with our expectations. We faced a really difficult comp, up 25% a year ago. So good to finish for the full year, right out of just over the top of the range we laid out to you guys at the beginning of the year.

componenttext: First, if you could discuss the potential for reductions in the disability reserve discount rate, given what's happened with interest rates? And maybe if you could provide us some sort of sensitivity on what a 50-basis-points change in the discount rate would do to your benefits ratio in the U.S. disability business?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Jimmmy. Jack, you want to take that?
componenttext: Okay, Jimmmy. Jack, you want to take that?

headline: Unum Group, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we've seen reductions. We've seen the interest rates fall since year-end. This is very similar to what happened last year, actually too during this period. It doesn't mean they're going to stay there for the full year, we've also said, seen spread
componenttext: Yes. So we've seen reductions. We've seen the interest rates fall since year-end. This is very similar to what happened last year, actually too during this period. It doesn't mean they're going to stay there for the full year, we've also said, seen spreads widening. I'd pull you back to the fourth quarter, where we're actually -- our new money rates were higher than we've seen in quite a while, and we're supportive of our reserve assumptions in both disability lines as well as long-term care lines. We keep track of that. We keep raising rates in response to the lower interest environment. We look for opportunities to book money to work at good yields. And it's something we'll look at during the year. I would say that we're pretty comfortable right now that relative to 2015, that we won't be forced to take a precipitous action because we have a good margin, interest margin now in our reserves. But it's something we continue to look at and decide as we do our reserve reviews.

componenttext: And the sensitivity is about 25 basis points, is about roughly $12 million in BTOE on an annualized basis, Jimmy.

componenttext: Okay. And then on long-term care, obviously, rates are challenging, but how are the other things going, like claims trends, your success in achieving price hikes versus what you might've assumed than you took the reserve charge in the fourth quarter of 2014?
