headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Unum Group Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the conference over to the Senior Vice President, Investo
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Unum Group Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the conference over to the Senior Vice President, Investor Relations, Mr. Tom White. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Glenn. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the second quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Unum. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact. As a res
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Glenn. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the second quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Unum. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact. As a result, actual results might differ materially from results suggested by these forward-looking statements.  Information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ appears in our filings with the SEC and are also located in the sections tittled Cautionary Statement regarding forward-looking statements and Risk Factors in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2015 and are subsequently filed on quarterly report of Form 10-Q. Our SEC filings can be found in the investor section of our website. 
I remind you that the statements in today's call speak only as of the date that they are made and we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. A presentation of the more directly comparable GAAP measures and the reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures included in today's presentation can be found in our statistical supplement also on our website and also in the investor section. 
Participating in this mornings conference call are Unum's President and CEO, Rick McKenney; and our CFO, Jack McGarry; as well as the CEOs of our core business segments: Mike Simonds for Unum US; Peter O'Donnell for Unum UK; and Tim Arnold for Colonial Life. And now, I'll turn the call over to Rick for his opening comments.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter results were excellent, with operating income per share of $0.99. This is an increase of 11% over last year. Together with our strong first quarter results, operating income per share grew 9%
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter results were excellent, with operating income per share of $0.99. This is an increase of 11% over last year. Together with our strong first quarter results, operating income per share grew 9% in the first half. Our operating trends have been very strong across the company., with solid levels of premium growth in Unum US, Unum UK, and Colonial Life, coupled with stable benefits experience and favorable expense management trends. 
I'm particularly pleased that we're achieving these strong results despite what has been a difficult business environment with historically low interest rates. The reason that we can deliver these consistent to improving results is, because we have a sound strategy and business plan in place. It is one that resonates well with our customers and the employee benefits marketplace, both on our exiting group solutions as well as the growing voluntary space. And it's our execution of the strategy that is generating strong financial outcomes. I'll discuss in more detail in a moment, but first I want to provide a few highlights on the second quarter. 
First, the premium growth that we're generating in our core operations remains very healthy at approximately 5% in each of our business lines. For the second quarter, premium income growth in Unum US was driven by strong persistency trends and our sales trends over this past several quarters. Total sales increased slightly in the second quarter with very strong performance in the voluntary and supplemental lines, offsetting a small decline in our employee benefit lines, where markets remain competitive. 
Unum U.K. premium growth benefited from the National Dental Plan acquisition from last year as well as growth in the Group Income Protection line. And finally, premium growth at Colonial Life was driven by the excellent sales trends we have seen over the past few years, which continued again this quarter with growth in new sales of 13%, bringing first half sales growth to just under 15%. 
Next, I'm very pleased we have maintained strong profit margins in our core business segments, while building this positive momentum in premium growth over the past several quarters. This shows the discipline we have bring to our markets and how we priced, underwrite and manage customer relationships in order to maintain the balance between producing topline growth and maintaining industry-leading profit margins. 
These strong operating results have a very strong level of statuary earnings in capital, which provides a substantial financial flexibility. Our first half statuary openings earnings have been outstanding, increasing 29% year-over-year to $400 million or just over. This enables us to continually generate free cash flow, which we have been used -- which we have used to create shareholder value through steady, consistent share repurchases and annual dividend increases.  At the same time, we're able to capitalize on attractive acquisition opportunities such as National Dental Plan in the U.K., and Starmount Life Insurance Company, which is also in the dental market, and we are able to capitalize them when they are available. 
So in summary, it's been a very strong first half of 2016 for the company. This performance is result of our steadfast focus on discipline execution of our business plan. This is reflected in many facets of our business, starting with our customers and includes how we underwrite in our prices business, how we manage clients to help people return to work, how we administer and enroll business and how we manage customer relationships. 
Operationally, we also continue to focus on disciplined expense management, which is evident in a favorable expense trends we have delivered in many of our business segments, which is also a net of the investments we are making in our businesses through such things customer facing technologies. When you combine this disciplined execution with our market positioning and growing footprint, we see a continuation of good profitable growth. 
And finally, I can't say enough about our people, who are responsible for this performance day-in, and day-out. We're committed to developing our talent, building over bench strength and ensuring our people continue to drive the changed necessary to remain the leader in the employee benefits marketplace. So those highlights are an excellent second quarter. I'll ask Jack to cover our results in greater detail. Jack?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Rick provided a high level of overview of our second quarter results and now I want provide a more in-depth view of the trends we saw in the quarter. First, I want to highlight the composition of our asset tax
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Rick provided a high level of overview of our second quarter results and now I want provide a more in-depth view of the trends we saw in the quarter. First, I want to highlight the composition of our asset tax operating income per share growth of 11.2%, which was well balanced between after-tax operating income and capital management. 
Operating income grew 5.9% over the year-ago quarter. This quarter was one of the strongest and best balanced quarters we've seen. In addition, the benefit from our share repurchase activity reduced our average shares outstanding by 4.8%, compared to the year-ago share count. A key driver of our success this quarter was the performance of Unum US. 
Second quarter operating income was very strong at $227.2 million, an increase of 12% on the year-ago quarter. Premium income growth continued it's positive trends, increasing 5.1% over the year-ago quarter. The benefit ratio for Unum US segment improved to 69.1% in the second quarter compared to 71.2% in the year-ago quarter. In addition, our focus on disciplined expense management was also contributed to operating results with the other expense ratio declining to 20.9% in the quarter, compared to 21.9% in the year-ago quarter. 
The profitability of our Unum US segment remains very strong with an operating ROE of 15.1% for the second quarter of 2016. 
Within the Unum US segment, operating income in our group disability business was $74.4 million in the second quarter of 2016, an increase of 21.6% over last year. Premium income increased 5% over the year-ago quarter, but pressure on net income continues, driven primarily by a lower portfolio yields. 
The benefit ratio was quite positive at 80.0% for the second quarter, compared to 83.4% in the year-ago quarter, as we continue to see lower new claim incidents and favorable claim recovery trends in our group long-term disability line, along with shorter claim duration periods in our group disability line. 
Group Life and AD&D operating income improved to $56.9 million for the second quarter, an increase of 8.4% from the year-ago quarter. Premium income grew 3.9% over the year-ago quarter, with the benefit ratio improved to 71.5% for the second quarter, compared to 73.1% in the year-ago quarter, it is by favorable Group Life wavier premium benefits. 
Operating income in the supplemental and voluntary lines was also very strong at $95.9 million in the second quarter of 2016, an increase of 7.6% over the year-ago quarter. Premium income growth trends remain favorable, increasing 6.7% in the quarter compared to last year. From a benefits perspective, overall results remain in line with our expectation, with favorable trends in the voluntary benefits line, offset by mildly elevated benefit ratios in the individual disability line. 
Looking at Unum UK. Operating income was GBP 25.7 million for the second quarter, an increase of 2.8% over the year-ago quarter. Premium income increased 5.7% over the year-ago quarter, driven by the acquisition of NDP and the growth in the group disability line. The benefit ratio was 70.1% for the second quarter, a slight improvement relative to the 70.7% in the year-ago quarter, as favorable risk experience in the disability line offset unfavorable expense in the life line.  Overall, profitability at the Unum UK segment remains quite strong with an operating ROE at 20.9% for the second quarter. 
It's too early to tell what the long-term impact that Brexit will have on our Unum UK operations. The low exchange rate will impact our results immediately in the third quarter. We do not expect to see much, if any impact to our risk results; however, if employment trends and wage inflation slowdown in the U.K., and interest rates remain underpressured, we could see some negative impact to our premium growth and investment income trends.  We believe that's the fundamental need for protection products in the U.K. has not changed as a result of the Brexit board, but we will be monitoring very closely for any impacts in our markets over the next several quarters. 
Colonial Life continued to generate strong steady results, with operating income of $77.9 million in the second quarter of 2016, compared to $77.6 million in the year-ago quarter. Premium income increased 4.6%, and the benefit ratio was 51.1% for the second quarter, compared to 50.4% for the year-ago quarter, due primarily to less favorable mortality experience in the life product line.  Colonial Life continues to generate excellent margins with an operating ROE up 17.4% for the quarter. 
In the second quarter, we competed our deck reviews for both our Unum US and Colonial Life businesses, with minimal impacts on second quarter results. 
Finally, for the Closed Block. Operating income was $32.6 million in the second quarter of 2016, compared to the exceptionally strong $36.6 million reported in the year-ago quarter. In the individual disability line, we saw very favorable underlining experience. The increase in the adjusted loss ratio to 84.3% in the second quarter from the 83.6% in the year-ago quarter, includes a reduction in the reserve discount rate to recognize the impact on future portfolio yields from the high level of bond calls and tenders during the second quarter of 2016.  Excluding this reduction and the discount rate, the interest adjusted loss ratio would have been slightly below 80%, one of our most favorable results in years. 
For the long-term care line, they interest adjusted loss ratio was 92.6% for the second quarter, compared to the unusually favorable 83.4% in the year-ago quarter. This swinging results demonstrates the volatility that this subject to on a quarterly basis and the importance of taking our longer-term view with the performance, which shows an interest adjusted loss ratio since our 4Q 2014 reserve review of 88.6%. The results in long-term this quarter were driven by an increase in new claim incidence and severity, brought on partly believe by the rate increase notifications that we delivered to policyholders recently. We expect that this is likely to continue in the near term and it's consistent with the claim activity behavior we've experienced in the past following rate increase notifications to policyholders.  As before, we expect these higher claim levels to remediate once we are through the rate increase notifications. 
I'm pleased that we continued to make good progress on achieving rate increases in our long-term care business. In addition to making good progress with state regulators, we're also seeing strong pickup of the lending spot option. The lending spot has the same positive impact on reservers as rate increases, but also has the added benefit of derisking the portfolio. Since the future claims will be smaller on the lending spot, the reserves will be somewhat less sensitive to future changes in reserve-less function. 
I'll move now to the growth trends we experienced across our business this quarter. Starting with Unum US, total sales increased 1.4% for the second quarter compared to a year ago. We continued to see competitive market particularly in the core market segment, where we continued to increase our rate to offset interest rate pressures. 
In total for LTD, STD and Group Life, we saw an overall decline in sales of 3.4% with core market sales down 9.9%, while large case sales increased 12.8%, reflecting continued success our ongoing efforts to increase penetration within existing customers. The momentum and our supplements on voluntary segments remain very encouraging. Our individual disability sales increased 12.3%, compared to a year ago quarter, driven by strong growth to existing customers. 
In the voluntary benefits product line, total sales increased 14% with a good balance between core market and large case sales. Persistency for Unum US is at very healthy levels. For the employee benefits lines combined, persistency was 90 -- 89.6%. This is important to us as we look to move price increases into our block to offset the impact of low interest rates and reduce discount rate assumptions that have been implemented in recent years. 
Our sales force does an excellent job of managing this balance of placing rate increases with maintaining our in-force business, which is essential to our ability to grow, while protecting the strong profit margins we have in our employee benefits block.  Likewise, voluntary benefits persistency of 76.7%, was favorable to the prior year results as was individual disability persistency at 91.3%. 
Sales in the Unum UK continue to rebound, increasing 19.4% in local currency with favorable trends in the core market for group long-term disability and group life overall, along with the benefit of the NDP acquisition. Persistency was favorable at 85.5%, helping to drive premium income growth of 5.7% this quarter. 
Finally, sales trends at Colonial Life remain very strong, increasing 13.3% for the second quarter and 14.5% for the first half of the year. Growth continues to be well balanced between the commercial market sector and the public sector and between sales to existing customers and sales to new accounts. Persistency for Colonial Life was slightly lower across all product lines in the quarter, but remains in line with our expectations. As a result, premium growth is showing steady momentum, increasing 4.6% in the second quarter compared to the year-ago quarter. 
Overall, we remain very pleased with the growth trends we see across our core business segments and as Rick highlighted earlier, the profit margins that we been able to sustain. 
Looking now at investment results. New money yields remain underpressure in the second quarter. However, I'm pleased that we're able again to exceed the new money yield assumption we have for our long-term care portfolio. We have exceeded our target of investing cash flows at 5% rate for every quarter since the 4Q 2014 reserve review. 
We remain well positioned with our Unum US long-term disability business from an interest rate perspective as our interest reserve margin remains very healthy. It's a great benefit to us as we navigate the interest rate that resulted from the Brexit referendum. It's too early to make a decision today on any future changes to the LTD discount rate for new claim but we remain satisfied that our -- with our margin at this time in a well tested ability to deliver the offsetting rate increases into the market should an adjustment be needed. 
The overall credit quality of our investment portfolio remains in very good shape. I'd like to highlight that further rebound in the net unrealized gain position of our energy holdings to $433 million at the end of the second quarter, compared to a gain of $19 million a quarter ago. It's impressive that the gross unrealized loss on energy holdings has declined to $85  --  $89.5 million at the end of the second quarter, compared to $297.4 million at the end of the first quarter. 
Energy holdings in a loss position were trading at over 90% of book value at the end of the second quarter. I believe, this validates the investment decisions in credit evaluation process we followed for the past several years, not just for our energy holdings, but for our management overall investment portfolio. 
Moving to capital management. It was another active quarter as we repurchased $100 million of our shares, consistent with our repurchase activity in recent quarters. Our holding company liquidity position remains very healthy at approximately $600 million as of quarter end, roughly twice the level we target for holding cas coverage for 1 year. 
This cash position is net of the $350 million we are holding for the debt maturity on September 30 contributions in the acquisition of Starmount Life Insurance Company. As a reminder, we issued $600 million in senior debt back in early May, in part to refinance this maturing date. 
Our risk based capital ratio for our traditional U.S. life insurance company remained at approximately 390%, well within our target range of 375 to 400 for this year. Statutory asset tax operating earnings were outstanding at $228.4 million for the second quarter of 2016, compared to $161.2 million in the year-ago quarter, an increase of 42%. This one of the best statutory quarters on record, reflecting the favorable risk experience across our primary business lines. 
For the first half of 2016, statutory after-tax operating earnings totaled $412.5 million, an increase of 29% over last year. 
Our outlook for growth and after-tax operating income per share for 2016 is unchanged with an expected growth rate of 3% to 6%. We now expect to be at the higher end of that range of the first half after-tax operating earnings per share growth has been a very healthy 9%. While we're not building that rate of growth into our expectations for the second half of the year, we remain very encouraged by our first-half trends. 
So to wrap up my comments, I'm very pleased with our first half results. In fact, been remarkable given the environment. We have executed very well on many parts of our strategy, including delivering rate increases and exceeding new money yield for long-term care, generating strong persistency growth in our core business segments and maintaining pricing discipline and delivering on renewals to help achieve strong profit margins. 
Given this progress, we enter the second half of the year highly confident in our ability to continue to create value in this difficult environment. Now I'll turn the call back to Rick.

So if I take all those things together, wouldn't that push out any kind of charges that you might have to take sort of towards the latter end of that typical 3 to 5-year timeframe that you've used in the past?

componenttext: We're very encouraged by the -- by where our investments have been. Although the last 6 quarters, I talked about we've exceeded the 5%. We exceed it by healthy margin. headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this maybe a tough one for Rick, but just -- it seems like no matter how good your core results are, the focus is always on the long-term care business. And I guess, I'm just wondering, does it make sense for this company to be part of a larger
componenttext: Okay. And this maybe a tough one for Rick, but just -- it seems like no matter how good your core results are, the focus is always on the long-term care business. And I guess, I'm just wondering, does it make sense for this company to be part of a larger organization, where you just don't get that volatility from this business, that is a non-core business, but is still sizable portion of your capital bay?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a fair question Sunnet, and I think that when we look at the company overall, we focused very much on our core operations making sure that we just ran great company in terms of the ongoing. And I think, you see the quarter and quarter, you seen over
componenttext:
It's a fair question Sunnet, and I think that when we look at the company overall, we focused very much on our core operations making sure that we just ran great company in terms of the ongoing. And I think, you see the quarter and quarter, you seen over the last several years, and we're going to continued to focus on that. 
On the Closed Block and more particularly on long-term care, it is a frustration to answer a lot of these questions. We think we do it very well. We're taking all the actions that we need to with regard to price increases, thinking about capital solutions, everything else. And so I think we're executing where want to on that block, but it certainly does garnered it's fair share of questions, and although frustration, we're going to keep working the same way we've been working. 
To get your broader question about the volatility and how that into our position as a company overall? I think we've been clear overtime that, do you want to look at what's in the best interest of our shareholders as well as all of our and when we think running our standalone company, that's how we think about it because we have the capital and the opportunity do so, so that's were we focused first. But as we think about other opportunities, it came at us, we certainly will do the right thing governance perspective and entertain those, but we're still very focused on running those core operations to the best business they can and taking all the actions necessary with regards to our Closed Block.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Just a couple on the yield. You've been able to earn against the long-term care. What -- you mentioned it was over 5%. I was wondering if you could specify exactly what it was in the quarter? And you mentioned, you were encouraged by the yields and so that would be more bullish in the commentary we're getting from a lot of companies on yields. So I'll be curious what kind of assets you're buying that are able to give you kind of good confidence around the risk-adjusted yield there?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you got to remember in the long-term care business, we were long-duration buyer. So our sweet spot is in the 30 year. The 30 year, you get still have a reasonably steep yield curve. There is a -- there has been a 70 to 80 basis point in the pickup in t
componenttext: So you got to remember in the long-term care business, we were long-duration buyer. So our sweet spot is in the 30 year. The 30 year, you get still have a reasonably steep yield curve. There is a -- there has been a 70 to 80 basis point in the pickup in the 30 year. There is also a credit curve. And so credit spreads of the 30 year are significantly higher than the credit spreads at the 10 year. The index over the past 6 quarters were BBB 30-year issuance has been well above 5%. Historically, we also use some other risk classes -- asset classes, whether it's a private placements or other things to help boost that yield. So largely, it's the fact that the longer end of the curve has maintained decent margins.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of follow-ups, what was it specifically in the quarter, just so we can track it better than new money rate?
componenttext: Just a couple of follow-ups, what was it specifically in the quarter, just so we can track it better than new money rate?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: We don't the new money rates.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But it was well over 5%. And then are the other asset classes, the alteratives your looking at, do they have a similar 30-year maturity or do they -- would they be higher yield, but shorter maturities than what you with the 30 year?
componenttext: Okay. But it was well over 5%. And then are the other asset classes, the alteratives your looking at, do they have a similar 30-year maturity or do they -- would they be higher yield, but shorter maturities than what you with the 30 year?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think one thing Randy, you are isolating a small piece of investment, although very important to us and something we're focused on. You have to look at the overall construct of our portfolio as well, and I think, you'll -- you won't see major shift
componenttext: Yes, I think one thing Randy, you are isolating a small piece of investment, although very important to us and something we're focused on. You have to look at the overall construct of our portfolio as well, and I think, you'll -- you won't see major shifts in our investment philosophy and how we run the portfolio, how we think about credit, how we incorporate private placements and other nonliquid assets in that mix. And we take all those things together, I think Jack said, we feel very good about hoe we done it over the last 18 months. Even in the quarter, we invested a little bit early as our investment team does when they see the good deals out there, they capture them. And so all those things come into play. We're not going to get into dissecting every investment we put behind, a particular line of business, particularly any particular quarter. So I think those comments are good. The interest rate environment is challenging,  we mentioned that, but our team continues to outperform, and we'll keep you up-to-date every quarter how we did.

componenttext: Jack, in your prepared remarks, you talked about the competitive landscape for the tradition life seem to be a picking up a little bit. Can you go a little bit detail in terms of what you're seeing in the traditional lines? And then also if you can comment on the voluntary business as well that would be helpful?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Humphrey, I'll actually look for Mike to respond to that.
componenttext: Yes, Humphrey, I'll actually look for Mike to respond to that.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you would have heard us talking about the new client acquisition pricing market in the group plans, probably about 3 quarters ago. We started to see it get a little bit more aggressive. And certainly, we've seen this cycle many times before. We are not
componenttext: So you would have heard us talking about the new client acquisition pricing market in the group plans, probably about 3 quarters ago. We started to see it get a little bit more aggressive. And certainly, we've seen this cycle many times before. We are not going to chase market share using price as a lever. And so we have seen some pressure on new client sales. We can't really control the competitive pricing environment. So we stay very focused on what we can control, which is first and foremost take care of our clients. Rick and Jack mentioned it before, but persistency over 90%, sales into these relationships were actually up 10% in the quarter and help to drive an overall increase in sales. And you put that together with persistency and you got really nice earned premium growth. A big part of what we're bringing into those client relationships as you highlighted is the voluntary line of business, 14% growth in the quarter, and really over the last several years, it's been a consistent growth story for voluntary as more and more for the employee as a decision-maker. We see the in the Unum branded business. We also see that really strong results coming at Colonial Life.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you mentioned in terms of the aggressive pricing, is the effect of you guys raising prices for interest rate or people actually lowering their pricing to get share?
componenttext: And you mentioned in terms of the aggressive pricing, is the effect of you guys raising prices for interest rate or people actually lowering their pricing to get share?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Humphrey and I'll give you the wholly unsatisfactory answer and a little bit of both. So we have put low-to-single digit increases, particularly in the long-term disability but in the group lines as well into our new business pricing, every 6 months
componenttext: Yes, Humphrey and I'll give you the wholly unsatisfactory answer and a little bit of both. So we have put low-to-single digit increases, particularly in the long-term disability but in the group lines as well into our new business pricing, every 6 months or so over the last 2 years, and that's been gradual, and our sales and client management teams have done a great job in taking that into the market. We would -- certainly that anticipate, given low rates into the competitive environment would need to follow suite. We haven't seen that happening. In fact, we've seen a few come back a bit more aggressively into the market and try to recapture some share they've lost over the last few years, and the combination of the 2, I think, is what's putting some pressure on the new client sales. But again, the aggregate, when you put it together, it's actually consistent topline growth, which we're pleased about.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then -- and a question on long-term care. For the recent lease announced, do you want to other public hearing for long-term care increase seems to be following Pennsylvania's footstep, do you expect more of these hearings from regulators
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then -- and a question on long-term care. For the recent lease announced, do you want to other public hearing for long-term care increase seems to be following Pennsylvania's footstep, do you expect more of these hearings from regulators as they try to strike a balance between protecting consumers and keeping the LTC business viable? And how does that -- these kind of hearings effect some of your rate increased divisions going forward?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, in general, these hearings have been positive for rate increases. I don't Pennsylvania held the hearings they approved the rate increase shortly thereafter. There was a successful hearing in Massachusetts. Maine actually held a hearing, was
componenttext: Yes, I think, in general, these hearings have been positive for rate increases. I don't Pennsylvania held the hearings they approved the rate increase shortly thereafter. There was a successful hearing in Massachusetts. Maine actually held a hearing, was one of the first. So we're happy to attend those hearings. We're really engaged in them. We have a very good story about, where our block is, the reasons we're chasing that we're pursuing rate increases, the justification for them, I think that the fact that we're not restore original pricing profitability into the block, that we're pursuing a sustainability strategy resonates well. And the lending spot option, that's get people an option to maintain their current premium level, while continuing to maintain extremely valuable benefits resonates well. So we're encouraged by the hearings and we think it is a catalyst for action.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Rick. I appreciate it for the question. So I think we look at the discounted rate on new claims incurred for LTD, but we look at in the context of the overall health of the business as well. We continue to see a good strong and favorable paid
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Rick. I appreciate it for the question. So I think we look at the discounted rate on new claims incurred for LTD, but we look at in the context of the overall health of the business as well. We continue to see a good strong and favorable paid incidence trends, both in terms of our count and severity. Very importantly, the recovery experience, our benefits team, the clinical and both resources continued to invest there and good So recovery trends have been very good as well. So as -- there is no crystal ball, it is a risk-taking business, but as we look forward, we feel very, very good about those fundamentals and that even if we're not need to make an adjustment on that new claim discount rate that it wouldn't have a material impact on the earnings trajectory for that group disability business.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So I just wanted to make sure that I'm interpreting that correctly. I mean, is that similar to saying that as underlying experience and underwriting is improving, your willing to maybe moved a little bit lower in that range, should be upper part of that range in terms of the margin on the discount rate?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that more to say, we've been continue to place rate increases. We've had favorable underwriting results. I think more of what we're saying is, if you look at that the trend we entered the year on the experience that's emerged underlying that b
componenttext: No, I think that more to say, we've been continue to place rate increases. We've had favorable underwriting results. I think more of what we're saying is, if you look at that the trend we entered the year on the experience that's emerged underlying that block would keep us on that same trend even after taking a discount rate charge.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Tom Gallagher with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll go next to Tom Gallagher with Evercore ISI.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start it off just on the long-term care claim side. So the higher claims that you're seeing following the rate increases, I guess, you've seen that before. So the expectations here is that you expected to be a temporary bleb. My question relat
componenttext: I wanted to start it off just on the long-term care claim side. So the higher claims that you're seeing following the rate increases, I guess, you've seen that before. So the expectations here is that you expected to be a temporary bleb. My question related to it is, aren't you come back though and you be coming back at least every couple of years on these rate increase filings? And should we expect if that's in fact the cause and effect here claims when you for rate increases, shouldn't we -- isn't that or -- shouldn't we think about that as more of a recurring issue if you keep coming back for a future rate increases?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't -- first of all, I don't think future rate increases is up for everything. We kept on coming back because the interest rate environment has deteriorated. You get more recent experience not only within Unum, but industry tables and things. I d
componenttext: Yes, I don't -- first of all, I don't think future rate increases is up for everything. We kept on coming back because the interest rate environment has deteriorated. You get more recent experience not only within Unum, but industry tables and things. I don't see -- this isn't always get worse for ever thing. I expect we'll get very close in the current filing to being where we need to be to support the sustainability of this business. There maybe some rate increase filings in the future. Those would be predicated on changes in our view of what the future of long-term care will be. So I don't see rate increases being forever in our future thing. You do get a mild in rate increases when you do them. And that's what we're seeing now, but we believe it's We actually, I think think have -- we are much more confident in where we are in long-term care and our ability to manage through, not only the short-term with our current reserve position, but managed through long-term care in general than I think others are.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jack, the -- just related to that, are you then, in terms of the level, if I don't know, maybe just a broad question, the level of rate that your asking for, are you actually getting around what you're requesting? It's sort of sounds like your based o
componenttext: And Jack, the -- just related to that, are you then, in terms of the level, if I don't know, maybe just a broad question, the level of rate that your asking for, are you actually getting around what you're requesting? It's sort of sounds like your based on that the way you responded it? Because I guess, what I've heard from some others is that, they might request 50% and they might get half of that, but then it spread out over 3 years, is that -- is my example still more the situation for you or your getting much closure to what you're requesting in terms of rate increases?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're getting what we expect to get, which is less than we request. But we didn't put what we requested into our reserve assumptions. We put our expectations. So in some states, you'll get 50%. In some states, it'll be spread out over 3 years. In the sche
componenttext: We're getting what we expect to get, which is less than we request. But we didn't put what we requested into our reserve assumptions. We put our expectations. So in some states, you'll get 50%. In some states, it'll be spread out over 3 years. In the scheme of things, that's not terribly material if it's spread out over 3 years, given the 40 years that the rest of it's going to run. So it depends by states, and many states have approved the full rate increase. Other states have approved the full rate increase, but required to be implemented over 3 years, but we have good data on how different states react and we built that data into what we're assuming in our reserve assumptions.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then if you think about -- can you just remind us your process for this year both timing -- do you -- is the actuarial review for long-term care, is that conducted in 3Q? And do you -- as part of your process, do you factor forwa
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then if you think about -- can you just remind us your process for this year both timing -- do you -- is the actuarial review for long-term care, is that conducted in 3Q? And do you -- as part of your process, do you factor forward interest rates? You look at the forward curve or do you look at the trailing because obviously forward rates matter a lot more than what you've accomplished the last 6 quarter? And do you -- based on, I guess the claims you've gotten to date, how much is that factor in or is that less impactful? Is it really most of interest rate issue at this point?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- I mean, we do our reserve reviews and not only on long-term care, but across-the-board. All of our reserve reviews in the company, we start those in the third quarter. They culminate. They come to conclusion in the fourth quarter. So that where
componenttext:
Yes, we -- I mean, we do our reserve reviews and not only on long-term care, but across-the-board. All of our reserve reviews in the company, we start those in the third quarter. They culminate. They come to conclusion in the fourth quarter. So that where we're confident in our year-end results, that would be the same timing for long-term care. 
In terms of what we look at going forward for the assumption on relying long-term care, we told you exactly what it was. Last time, it was 5% for 4 to 5 years and a reversion to the long-term mean thereafter. We will come up with a -- should we -- but when we test, we'll come with a reasonable assumption that we believe in and that it's audited by rates by external auditors. It's not necessarily the forward curve, but it's a reasonable assumption.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then just my final question is, the -- I guess one of the things that surprised me a little bit was the increase in financial leverage. So pro forma to debt pay down that you expect in 3Q, you're going to be at a 27% debt to cap. And I guess, what's
componenttext: Okay. Then just my final question is, the -- I guess one of the things that surprised me a little bit was the increase in financial leverage. So pro forma to debt pay down that you expect in 3Q, you're going to be at a 27% debt to cap. And I guess, what's surprising me a little bit is there hasn't really been much in a way extraordinary needs that you have done a few small acquisitions, but nothing too big, so why is the leverage gone up certainly? And it also sort of stands out when you just had a great statuary earnings quarter, where the cash generation looks pretty good, but why the increase financial leverage -- is there a need for cash more or what's happening?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. First of all, we feel very comfortable with where we are. At 27%, there is -- it is a comfortable place where. We have great coverage ratios. So we don't view 27% as being problematic. With that said, we didn't pre-fund the debt maturity in September
componenttext: No. First of all, we feel very comfortable with where we are. At 27%, there is -- it is a comfortable place where. We have great coverage ratios. So we don't view 27% as being problematic. With that said, we didn't pre-fund the debt maturity in September when we purchased -- when we announced the acquisition, we talk about the funding a portion of that and debt. And just when we looked at our capital plans and where our leverage would end up, it made sense to -- it made sense that it didn't make a little bit bigger. Debt issuance given the rates at that time and things were, and given what we thought our equity growth would be through 2017. So we're very comfortable where we are. We expected to come down over the ensuing few quarters, but there is nothing remarkable about it.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So no issues with the rating agencies with the higher level?
componenttext: Okay. So no issues with the rating agencies with the higher level?

componenttext: Whatsoever.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to take you back, we decided to vote for exit late June, and the immediate impact was quite volatile. So we saw equities dropped both for the 4000, 4250. They pretty much come back now to where they were at pre-Brexit. We did see risk-free rate up as
componenttext:
Just to take you back, we decided to vote for exit late June, and the immediate impact was quite volatile. So we saw equities dropped both for the 4000, 4250. They pretty much come back now to where they were at pre-Brexit. We did see risk-free rate up as well, that hasn't come back well. And obviously, the thing your seeing in our results is the exchange rate dropping to around about a $1.32. And I think one of the things that if it stays there, you will see continued pressure because our average exchange rates we're using at the moment -- in the 140s, so that will come down if it at $1.32. What I would say, it's uncertain environment and it's new for to see whats going to happen to the economy. 
Looking to the U.K. If you take our investment portfolio, I mean, Jack's talked about this already, we're very well positioned -- financial stocks and feel very good about the investment portfolio and the robustness of that. 
And if you take the revenue, and we have exposure to particularly some of the big financial services firms, in talking to them though, very few have definitive plans about what they're going to do yet. Again, there are more cautious, I would say, and we saw a bit of that come through our premiums in the first half. And so therefore, they're not investing in recruiting people, perhaps taking -- have a cost of control on the benefits plans, but nothing material, I would say, yet coming through that would affect us. 
And to your questions on benefits. Actually, on the last recession, we didn't see a lot of impact on our benefit ratio. We saw something called presentism. People worried about their jobs and actually not going that was bit cyclical aspect for us. So our business model brings very robust. And so we're very pretty happy that we've got a good focus on the risk-free rise and what the impacts of that might be. The area that is more difficult to call is the new money rates risk fees dropped. Clearly, the 10-year bond is below 1% for U.K. And again like the U.S., we've gotten a proven track record of putting rate through will probably dampen growth a bit because not all our competitors are as disciplined as Unum is both in the U.S. and U.K., but we'll have to see how that works And really, as we go through the next few months and the government begins to set out it's position, we'll get a clear picture and be able to update you on the impacts as that becomes more clear. I just finished that. We got a strong business model, that's well positioned to manage Brexit. That's what I was going to say Rick.

componenttext: Yes, I'd say across the board, it's reasonably competitive. Where we feel it is most acutely would be in the middle market, so that's typically employers in the say 250 employees, up to 5,000. Typically, you've got competitors in this phase focused very large case, but they will go down into the mid, and then you have small employer focused carriers that will and that takes into the mid. And so pretty much that can get a crowded space. And when prices get a little bit soft, we find it a difficult place business within our pricing parameters, but again, it's much work to be done between now and the end of the year, and we feel like we've got a good value proposition to into the market. So that what we probably felt it most acutely.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's a it's been something that we've seen and its kind of like waking a sleeping dog when they get the rate noted and it's not only the policyholder, but it's -- very often the caregivers or children of the policyholder. Oftentimes, an old p
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's a it's been something that we've seen and its kind of like waking a sleeping dog when they get the rate noted and it's not only the policyholder, but it's -- very often the caregivers or children of the policyholder. Oftentimes, an old person can go into an assisted living facility and not even realize that they have the coverage even though they still paying out, and that rate increase comes out as a reminder. And that reminder sparks people to apply for the benefits. You get some applications with that, people who are already have been in a facility for a while, who are looking for back payments, so that affects the loss ratio. And it just becomes an increase. We actually looked over the past couple of quarters at the incident rate that people who received a notification versus the rate on the people who are -- who will be receiving them, but haven't received them yet, and there is a 10% to 15% difference between those 2 with the ones being notified being 10% to 15% higher. It impacts severity of claims as well because that lending is focused on people with inflation riders and so they tend to have higher benefits. We've seen it in the past. It's going to last for a while as we work through those rate increases, but we do believe that is something will abate over time.

componenttext: We -- I think shock lapse is relative. If your lapse rate goes up 0.1% or 0.2%, and it is big relative to the rate, but I'm not sure I'd call out a lapse. And than in particular because the lending spot provides the option to maintain their current premium, we would expect to see even a less of a persistency impact from these rate increases.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you pay the rate increase, your benefit continued to grow at 5% compound annual rate. So those who paid the rate increase have a bigger benefit it out there, and that additional premium pays for that benefit bucket. If you take a lending spot,
componenttext: Yes. So if you pay the rate increase, your benefit continued to grow at 5% compound annual rate. So those who paid the rate increase have a bigger benefit it out there, and that additional premium pays for that benefit bucket. If you take a lending spot, they compound of 3%. So the ultimate benefit that you pay down the road are significantly smaller than they would been as you paid the premium. As you realize fluctuations, whether it's is interest rate fluctuations or underlying experience fluctuations, they don't effect premiums, they effect the benefits much more severely. And so by having a smaller pool out there, you are less sensitive to interest rates or mortality fluctuations.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, the premiums are not as -- they are not sensitive to those things as the benefits are. If they -- if you're going to have higher incidence down the road, premiums don't react to that benefit. It is a little like a derisking a pension plan.

componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Unum Group Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the conference over to the Senior Vice President, Investor Relations, Mr. Tom White. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Gwen. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the second quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Unum. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact. As a resu
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Gwen. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the second quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Unum. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact. As a result, actual results might differ materially from results suggested by these forward-looking statements. Information concerning factors that could cause results to differ appears in our filings with the SEC and are also located in the sections titled Cautionary Statement regarding forward-looking statements and Risk Factors in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2015, and are subsequently filed quarterly report on Form 10-Q. Our SEC filings can be found in the Investors Section of our website. 
I remind you that the statements in today's call speak only as of date they are made, and we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. A presentation of the most directly comparable GAAP measures and reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures included in today's presentation can be found in our statistical supplement on our website, also in the Investors Section. 
Participating in this morning's conference call are Unum's President and CEO, Rick McKenney; and our CFO, Jack McGarry; as well as the CEOs of our core business segments: Mike Simonds for Unum US; Peter O'Donnell for Unum UK; and Tim Arnold for Colonial Life. 
And now I'll turn the call over to Rick for his opening comments.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter results were excellent, with operating income per share of $0.99. This is an increase of 11% over last year. Together with our strong first quarter results, operating income per share grew 9%
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter results were excellent, with operating income per share of $0.99. This is an increase of 11% over last year. Together with our strong first quarter results, operating income per share grew 9% in the first half. Our operating trends have been very strong across the company, with solid levels of premium growth in Unum US, Unum UK and Colonial Life, coupled with stable benefits experience and favorable expense management trends. 
I am particularly pleased that we're achieving these strong results despite what has been a difficult business environment with historically low interest rates. The reason that we can deliver these consistent to improving results is because we have a sound strategy and business plan in place. It is one that resonates well with our customers in the employee benefits marketplace, both on our existing group solutions as well as the growing voluntary space. And it's our execution of the strategy that is generating these strong financial outcomes. I'll discuss this in more detail in a moment, but first, I want to provide a few highlights on the second quarter. 
First, the premium growth we are generating in our core operations remains very healthy at approximately 5% in each of our business lines. For the second quarter, premium income growth in Unum US was driven by strong persistency trends and our sales trends over these past several quarters. Total sales increased slightly in the second quarter with very strong performance in the voluntary and supplemental lines, offsetting a small decline in our employee benefit lines, where markets remain competitive. Unum U.K. premium growth benefited from the National Dental Plan acquisition from last year as well as growth in the Group Income Protection line. And finally, premium growth at Colonial Life was driven by the excellent sales trends we have seen over the past few years, which continued again this quarter, with growth in new sales of 13%, bringing first half sales growth to just under 15%. 
Next, I'm very pleased we have maintained strong profit margins in our core business segments while building this positive momentum in premium growth over the past several quarters. This showed the discipline we are bringing to our markets in how we price, underwrite and manage customer relationships in order to maintain the balance between producing top line growth and maintaining industry-leading profit margins. 
These strong operating results drive a very strong level of statutory earnings in capital, which provides a substantial financial flexibility. Our first half statutory operating earnings have been outstanding, increasing 29% year-over-year to $400 million or just over. This enables us to continually generate free cash flow, which we have been used -- which we have used to create shareholder value through steady, consistent share repurchases and annual dividend increases.  At the same time, we're able to capitalize on attractive acquisition opportunities such as National Dental Plan in the U.K., and Starmount Life Insurance Company, which is also in the dental market, and we are able to capitalize them when they are available. 
So in summary, it's been a very strong first half of 2016 for the company. This performance is a result of our steadfast focus on disciplined execution of our business plan. This is reflected in many facets of our business, starting with our customers and includes how we underwrite in price business, how we manage claims to help people return to work, how we administer and enroll business and how we manage customer relationships. 
Operationally, we also continue to focus on disciplined expense management, which is evident in the favorable expense trends we have delivered in many of our business segments, which is also a net of the investment we are making in our businesses through such things as customer-facing technologies. When you combine this disciplined execution with our market positioning and growing footprint, we see a continuation of good profitable growth. 
And finally, I can't say enough about our people, who are responsible for this performance day-in and day-out. We're committed to developing our talent, building our bench strength and ensuring our people continue to drive the changes necessary to remain the leader in the employee benefits marketplace. 
So with those highlights on an excellent second quarter, I'll ask Jack to cover our results in greater detail. Jack?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Rick provided a high-level overview of our second quarter results, and now I want provide a more in-depth view of the trends we saw in the quarter. First, I want to highlight the composition of our after-tax
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Rick provided a high-level overview of our second quarter results, and now I want provide a more in-depth view of the trends we saw in the quarter. 
First, I want to highlight the composition of our after-tax operating income per share growth of 11.2%, which was well balanced between after-tax operating income growth and capital management.  Operating income grew 5.9% over the year-ago quarter. This quarter was one of the strongest and best balanced quarters we've seen. In addition, the benefit from our share repurchase activity reduced our average shares outstanding by 4.8% compared to the year-ago share count. 
A key driver of our success this quarter was the performance of Unum US. Second quarter operating income was very strong at $227.2 million, an increase of 12% from the year-ago quarter. Premium income growth continued it's positive trends, increasing 5.1% over the year-ago quarter. The benefit ratio for Unum US segment improved to 69.1% in the second quarter compared to 71.2% in the year-ago quarter. 
In addition, our focus on disciplined expense management was -- also contributed to operating results, with the other expense ratio declining to 20.9% in the quarter compared to 21.9% in the year-ago quarter. The profitability of our Unum US segment remained very strong, with an operating ROE of 15.1% for the second quarter of 2016. 
Within the Unum US segment, operating income in our group disability business was $74.4 million in the second quarter of 2016, an increase of 21.6% over last year. Premium income increased 5% over the year-ago quarter, but pressure on net investment income continues, driven primarily by lower portfolio yields. 
The benefit ratio was quite positive at 80.0% for the second quarter compared to 83.4% in the year-ago quarter, as we continue to see lower new claims incidents and favorable claim recovery trends in our group long-term disability line, along with shorter claim duration periods in our group short-term disability line. 
Group Life and AD&D operating income improved to $56.9 million for the second quarter, an increase of 8.4% from the year-ago quarter. Premium income grew 3.9% over the year-ago quarter, with the benefit ratio improved to 71.5% for the second quarter compared to 73.1% in the year-ago quarter, aided by favorable Group Life waiver of premium benefits. 
Operating income in the supplemental and voluntary lines was also very strong at $95.9 million in the second quarter of 2016, an increase of 7.6% over the year-ago quarter. Premium income growth trends remained favorable, increasing 6.7% in the quarter compared to last year. From a benefits perspective, overall results remain in line with our expectation, with favorable trends in the voluntary benefits line, offset by mildly elevated benefit ratios in the individual disability line. 
Looking at Unum UK. Operating income was GBP 25.7 million for the second quarter, an increase of 2.8% over the year-ago quarter. Premium income increased 5.7% over the year-ago quarter, driven by the acquisition of NDP and the growth of the group disability line. The benefit ratio was 70.1% for the second quarter, a slight improvement relative to the 70.7% in the year-ago quarter, as favorable risk experience in the disability line offsets some unfavorable experience in the life line.  Overall, profitability at the Unum UK segment remains quite strong, with an operating ROE at 20.9% for the second quarter. 
It's too early to tell what the long-term impact that Brexit will have on our Unum UK operations. The lower exchange rate will impact our results immediately in the third quarter. We do not expect to see much, if any, impact to our risk results; however, if employment trends and wage inflation slowdown in the U.K. and interest rates remain under pressure, we could see some negative impact to our premium growth and investment income trends.  We believe that the fundamental need for protection products in the U.K. has not changed as a result of the Brexit vote, but we will be monitoring very closely for any impacts in our markets over the next several quarters. 
Colonial Life continued to generate strong steady results, with operating income of $77.9 million in the second quarter of 2016 compared to $77.6 million in the year-ago quarter. Premium income increased 4.6%, and the benefit ratio was 51.1% for the second quarter compared to 50.4% for the year-ago quarter, due primarily to less favorable mortality experience in the life product line.  Colonial Life continues to generate excellent margins, with an operating ROE of 17.4% for the quarter. 
In the second quarter, we completed our DAC reviews for both our Unum US and Colonial Life businesses, with minimal impacts on second quarter results. 
Finally, for the Closed Block. Operating income was $32.6 million in the second quarter of 2016 compared to the exceptionally strong $36.6 million reported in the year-ago quarter. In the individual disability line, we saw very favorable underlying experience. The increase in the interest adjusted loss ratio to 84.3% in the second quarter from 83.6% in the year-ago quarter includes a reduction in the reserve discount rate to recognize the impact on future portfolio yields from the high level of bond calls and bond tenders during the second quarter of 2016. Excluding this reduction and the discount rate, the interest adjusted loss ratio would have been slightly below 80%, one of our most favorable results in years. 
For the long-term care line, the interest adjusted loss ratio was 92.6% for the second quarter compared to the unusually favorable 83.4% in the year-ago quarter. This swing in results demonstrates the volatility that this block is subject to on a quarterly basis and the importance of taking our longer-term view with the performance, which shows an interest adjusted loss ratio since our 4Q 2014 reserve review of 88.6%. 
The results in long-term this quarter were driven by an increase in new claim incidence and severity, brought on in part, we believe, by the rate increase notifications that we delivered to policyholders recently. We expect that this is likely to continue in the near term and is consistent with the claim activity behavior we've experienced in the past following rate increase notifications to policyholders.  As before, we expect these higher-claim levels to remediate once we are through the rate increase notifications. 
I'm pleased that we continued to make good progress on achieving rate increases in our inforce long-term care business. In addition to making good progress with state regulators, we're also seeing strong pickup of the lending spot option. The lending spot has the same positive impact on reserves as rate increases, but also has the added benefit of derisking the portfolio. Since future claims will be smaller under the lending spot, the reserves will be somewhat less sensitive to future changes in reserve assumptions. 
I'll move now to the growth trends we experienced across our business this quarter. Starting with Unum US, total sales increased 1.4% for the second quarter compared to a year ago. We continued to see competitive market completions, particularly in the core market segment, where we continued to increase our rates to offset interest rate pressures. 
In total for LTD, STD and Group Life, we saw an overall decline in sales of 3.4%, with core market sales down 9.9% while large case sales increased 12.8%, reflecting continued success in our ongoing efforts to increase penetration within existing customers. 
The momentum in our supplemental and voluntary segments remain very encouraging. Our individual disability sales increased 12.3% compared to a year-ago quarter, driven by strong growth to existing customers. In the voluntary benefits product line, total sales increased 14%, with a good balance between core market and large case sales. 
Persistency for Unum US is at very healthy levels. For the employee benefits lines combined, persistency was 90 -- 89.6%. This is important to us as we look to move price increases into our inforce block to offset the impact of low interest rates and reduce discount rate assumptions that have been implemented in recent years. 
Our sales force does an excellent job of managing this balance of placing rate increases with maintaining our inforce business, which is essential to our ability to grow while protecting the strong profit margins we have in our employee benefits block.  Likewise, voluntary benefits persistency of 76.7% was favorable to the prior year results as was individual disability persistency at 91.3%. 
Sales in the Unum UK continue to rebound, increasing 19.4% in local currency, with favorable trends in the core market for group long-term disability and group life overall, along with the benefit of the NDP acquisition. Persistency was favorable at 85.5%, helping to drive premium income growth of 5.7% this quarter. 
Finally, sales trends at Colonial Life remain very strong, increasing 13.3% for the second quarter and 14.5% for the first half of the year. Growth continues to be well balanced between the commercial market sector and the public sector and between sales to existing customers and sales to new accounts. Persistency for Colonial Life was slightly lower across all product lines in the quarter, but remains in line with our expectations. As a result, premium growth is showing steady momentum, increasing 4.6% in the second quarter compared to the year-ago quarter. 
Overall, we remain very pleased with the growth trends we see across our core business segments and, as Rick highlighted earlier, the profit margins that we've been able to sustain. 
Looking now at investment results. New money yields remain under pressure in the second quarter. However, I'm pleased that we were able again to exceed the new money yield assumption we have for our long-term care portfolio. We have exceeded our target of investing cash flows at 5% rate for every quarter since the 4Q 2014 reserve review. 
We remain well positioned with our Unum US long-term disability business from an interest rate perspective as our interest reserve margin remains very healthy. It's a great benefit to us as we navigate the dip in interest rates that resulted from the Brexit referendum. It's too early to make a decision today on any future changes to the LTD discount rate for new claim incurrals, but we remain satisfied that our -- with our margin at this time in a well-tested and proven ability to deliver the offsetting rate increases into the market, should an adjustment be needed. 
The overall credit quality of our investment portfolio remains in very good shape. I'd like to highlight the further rebound in the net unrealized gain position of our energy holdings to $433 million at the end of the second quarter compared to a gain of $19 million a quarter ago. It's impressive that the gross unrealized loss on energy holdings has declined to $85  --  $89.5 million at the end of the second quarter compared to $297.4 million at the end of the first quarter. 
Energy holdings in a loss position were trading at over 90% of book value at the end of the second quarter. I believe this validates the investment decisions in credit evaluation process we followed for the past several years, not just for our energy holdings, but for our management of the overall investment portfolio. 
Moving to capital management. It was another active quarter as we repurchased $100 million of our shares, consistent with our repurchase activity in recent quarters. Our holding company liquidity position remains very healthy at approximately $600 million as of quarter end, roughly twice the level we target for holding company cash coverage needs for 1 year. 
This cash position is net of the $350 million we are holding for the debt maturity on September 30 for contributions in the acquisition of Starmount Life Insurance Company. As a reminder, we issued $600 million in senior debt back in early May, in part, to refinance this maturing debt. 
Our risk-based capital ratio for our traditional U.S. life insurance companies remained at approximately 390%, well within our target range of 375% to 400% for this year. Statutory asset tax operating earnings were outstanding at $228.4 million for the second quarter of 2016 compared to $161.2 million in the year-ago quarter, an increase of 42%. This one is the best statutory quarters on record, reflecting the favorable risk experience across our primary business lines. 
For the first half of 2016, statutory after-tax operating earnings totaled $412.5 million, an increase of 29% over last year. Our outlook for growth and after-tax operating income per share for 2016 is unchanged, with an expected growth rate of 3% to 6%. We now expect to be at the higher end of that range as the first half after-tax operating earnings per share growth has been a very healthy 9%. While we're not building that rate of growth into our expectations for the second half of the year, we remain very encouraged by our first half trends. 
So to wrap up my comments, I'm very pleased with our first half results. In fact, I'd stated they're remarkable given the environment. We have executed very well on many parts of our strategy, including delivering rate increases and exceeding new money yield targets for long-term care, generating strong persistency in growth in our core business segments and maintaining pricing discipline and delivering on renewals to help achieve strong profit margins. 
Given this progress, we enter the second half of the year highly confident in our ability to continue to create value in this difficult environment. Now I'll turn the call back to Rick.

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Jack. As we go to your questions, I'll conclude by reiterating how pleased we are with the second quarter and first half results. We continue to see good premium growth, stable benefits experience, the benefit of disciplined expense mana
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Jack. As we go to your questions, I'll conclude by reiterating how pleased we are with the second quarter and first half results. We continue to see good premium growth, stable benefits experience, the benefit of disciplined expense management and strong capital generation. I am very encouraged by these trends as I believe they will continue to serve us well. 
We'll now move to your questions. So I'll ask Gwen to begin the Q&A session. Gwen?

componenttext: So just wanted to start with long-term care also. So as you mentioned here, since the charge, you've beaten your bogey of 5% every quarter. So if I take all of those things together, wouldn't that push out any kind of charge that you might have to take sort of towards the latter end of that typical 3- to 5-year time frame that you've used in the past?

componenttext: We're very encouraged by the -- by where our investments have been. Although the last 6 quarters, I talked about we've exceeded the 5%. We have exceeded it by a healthy margin. headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this maybe a tough one for Rick, but just -- it seems like no matter how good your core results are, the focus is always on the long-term care business. And I guess, I'm just wondering, does it make sense for this company to be part of a larger
componenttext: Okay. And this maybe a tough one for Rick, but just -- it seems like no matter how good your core results are, the focus is always on the long-term care business. And I guess, I'm just wondering, does it make sense for this company to be part of a larger organization, where you just don't get that volatility from this business that is a non-core business but is still sizable portion of your capital bay?

headline: Unum Group, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a fair question, Suneet. And I think that when we look at the company overall, we focused very much on our core operations to make it sure that we just ran great companies in terms of the ongoing. And I think you see that quarter-in, quarter-out, you
componenttext: It's a fair question, Suneet. And I think that when we look at the company overall, we focused very much on our core operations to make it sure that we just ran great companies in terms of the ongoing. And I think you see that quarter-in, quarter-out, you've certainly seen it over the last several years. And we're going to continue to focus on that.  On the Closed Block and more particularly, on long-term care, it is a frustration to answer a lot of these questions. We think we do it very well. We're taking all of the actions that we need to with regards to price increases, thinking about capital solutions, everything else. And so I think we're executing where we want to on that block, but it certainly does garnered it's fair share of questions. And although with frustration, we're going to keep working the same way we've been working.  To get to your broader question about the volatility and how that weaves into our position as a company overall? I think we've been clear over time that, do you want to look at what's in the best interest of our shareholders as well as all of our constituencies. And when we think about running our standalone company, that's how we think about it, because we have the -- well, with all the capital and the opportunity do so, so that's where we focused first. But as we think about other opportunities, if they came at us, we certainly would do our -- do the right thing from a governance perspective and entertain those. But we're still very focused on running those core operations to be the best business they can and taking all the actions necessary with regards to our Closed Block.
